mods.abstract: Michael Lucido's electric-box mural features two sunglass-wearing raccoons on the back. A raccoon holding a video camera in its right hand while flashing a "sign of the horns" gesture (the index finger and the little finger are upright and the thumb is clasped against the two middle fingers) on his left hand sits atop the shoulders of the other raccoon who is performing a kick flip on a sky-blue skateboard with pink wheels, the words "Rad Thief" ( a reference to the name of Lucido's clothing company: Rad Thief) appear on the bottom of the board. The raccoons are painted against a teal, yellow, and pink background. The skateboarding theme of this box possibly relates to its location at City Park Plaza, used in the past as an unofficial skate park. The video camera might be symbolic Lucido's involvement with the multi-media production.

mods.abstract: The eastern wall of the Circus Circus Reno contains seven 20 x 14 ft. panels, each painted by a different artist during the 2017 24-Hour Mural Marathon competition. From left to right: Anthony Ortega won the competition with a psychedelic mural composition that combines ancient Mesoamerican art with futuristic elements. This mural is painted with vibrant shades of blue, red, green, orange, yellow, pink, and purple, portraying a vivid ancient Mesoamerican god-like figure that emerges from the stellar depths of the galaxy behind it and begins it descent into the green forest that surrounds the outer edges of the mural; Kendel Leslie painted a colorful mural with a blue humpback whale as the primary subject. The whale is painted in several shades of blue and purple. The background is composed of different shapes and formed in light pink, magenta, lime green, pastel yellow and purple among a black background with white stars, alluding to a galaxy-like ocean; Artist Raphael Blanco's mural d

mods.abstract: The mural on the two adjacent back walls of Mountain Music Parlor was painted by a group of youth who are part of the Children's Cabinet's "Spray Positive" program. This program was instigated by the Reno Police Department, in collaboration with the Children's Cabinet, as a way to beautify blighted properties in Midtown and Downtown Reno. A dream catcher with music notes in the web leads to the head of a Native-American figure wearing an elaborate headdress. An American flag emerges from the left side of the headdress and straddles both walls. A portrait of a man in a cowboy hat (most likely bluegrass musician Bill Monroe) painted in front of the flag graces the adjacent wall, and the mural concludes with a rendering of a chick playing a cello with the name "Bill Monroe" painted above it.

mods.abstract: Kendel Leslie's signal-box mural is dedicated to the preservation of Nevada's wilderness and wildlife. Leslie has painted a public-service announcement on the back side of the box: the words "Do your part, stand up for wildlife" with the outline of a heart at the end and the silhouettes of various animals (bighorn sheep, pronghorn antelope, mountain bluebird, jackrabbit, and coyote) have been encased in a gray rectangle with curvy edges. A sky with rolling white clouds appears above. Blue, green, and yellow rolling hills appear below. In the bottom-right corner, a jackrabbit stands in the dessert landscape. Leslie's name and Facebook address (Facebook.com/KendelsArt) are painted in black in the bottom-right corner.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock depicts a cowboy riding a wild mustang into the sunset, representative of the Reno Rodeo, in this mural painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. A halo of barbed wire floats above the cowboy's hat and a locomotive disguises itself in the body of the mustang. The background is painted bright blue with a beige banner swirling across it that reads "Get Buck Get Broke." Objects, such as grape bundles, crowns (a common object in Rock's murals), hearts and cherries speckle the mural's background.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.

record.Title: Nevada; Nevada Row

mods.abstract: A woman and young boy dance together in this mural by Erik Burke. Their bodies and garments are painted using the same palette of browns, reds, and greens. The boy wears a long-sleeved shirt with teal stripes around the forearms, upper arms and chest, matching the string of pearls worn by the woman. Two bright green-flanked-by-white stripes run through the mural, a curved one along the top and a straight one along the bottom. Starting near the left elbow of the boy, bright pink flowers interspersed with black dots run around and then through the dancers. A raven appears on the left side of the mural, perched atop the building's awning. The mural is 26 x 60 ft.

mods.abstract: Ponderous, painted by Erik Burke on a metal meat freezer at Ponderosa Meat & Provision Co., features a portrait of John Muir on the left in front of snow-covered mountains and a body of water, flanked by an open hand about to receive a pine cone, with white and gray stripes running through the scene. Burke used a simple color palette consisting of white, black, grays and browns. The description of the mural on Burke's website is as follows: "Correlating the etymology of the building's namesake and John Muir, a profound advocate for the preservation and enjoyment of the nearby Sierras. The mural places a pondering and monochromatic Muir in a winter landscape next to a hand catching a falling pinecone as an allegory for the weight of man's relationship with nature. A trinity of lines helps order the various planes and build a stage of depth."

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a not-so-typical day at the beach. A woman, half human and half mermaid, with the words "Mer-Maid in the Shade" painted along her tail, suns herself on a beach populated by beach balls, towels, umbrellas and other beach goers, such as the two children building a sand castle. Above the beach is a crumbling-city skyline caused by the lashing tail of the spotted sea creature that swims in the ocean below. An orca emerges from the water above the words "Life's a Beach" and a bright orange sun wearing shutter shades hangs in the sky.

mods.abstract: This gypsy-like woman, painted by artist Anthony Ortega, fashions a combination of deep-red and golden-yellow hair, wrapped in a green and white gypsy headscarf, embellished with a vibrant yellow flower. She is also accented with dangling golden earrings, blue sleeves, and detailed floral designs on her shoulders. She holds a cocktail in her left hand, displaying her connection to Davidson's distillery, the place upon which the mural was painted.

mods.abstract: This painted-wall sign welcomes those driving past it to Dickerson Road, an area west of downtown Reno, running parallel to the Truckee River, that is referred to as "'Reno’s Industrial Arts District,' combining art, commercial and residential properties, and a nature preserve." Using bright and vibrant colors, Eric (Erik) Burke and Buz Rhodes painted large block letters, with orange and red shadows behind them, to spell out "Dickerson," with imagery and scenes appearing in each letter that signify and represent the nature of the district. The "D" features an angle grinder cutting metal; a paint brush stands in for the "I"; the "C" features the profile of half of a sandwich; the "K" displays a smith forging a piece of metal; the "E" shows someone wearing tan pants and brown boots laying under the hood of a vehicle; the "R" features a woman's body in profile from her lower torso to the top of her knees, wearing a black and white striped undergarment, with red rose vines over the entire image; the "S" contains water with green and purple lily pads floating on top; the "O" is made up of a figure wearing tan garments throwing on a yellow pottery wheel; and the "N" includes a variety of multicolored metal bottle caps. The words "Welcome to" and "Live, Work, Eat, Play" appear in red and blue on a white banner painted on the left side of the mural. The artists' names,"Eric Burke and Buz Rhodes," appear in red and blue on a white banner painted in the upper far-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: This hardware-themed mural was painted by artist Joe C. Rock on the southern wall of Ace Hardware in Midtown Reno. On the left side of the mural, a can of red paint pours down from the top onto a wooden paint stirrer stick with the Ace logo on it. On the left, a paint brush has been dipped in the red paint and a paint roller above the brush has been rolled in the paint. In the scene on the right side of the mural, a man wearing a white chef's hat and apron is barbecuing or deep frying a turkey in a fenced-in yard surrounded by tall pine trees. Rock has utilized the natural brick facade of the wall to depict the brick patio the man stands on, and the blue sky behind and above him flows into the blue label on the paint can.

mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural set against a light blue background depicts a camera with a roll of film unraveling from its film compartment. On the unraveled film can be seen the undeveloped images that the camera has captured. A girl holds her dog; a man hangs out the driver-side window of a van and looks at the camera; a man kneels in front of his bicycle; two children ride their bicycles; a man looks to his left with a city street behind him; a man holds two bags (one in each hand) up in the air and smiles at the camera; a woman stands with her hands in her pockets and smiles at the camera; a young girl looks quizzically at the camera; a young man looks back at the camera from the driver-side window of his car; a man stands with his hands in his pockets in front of a light pole; a man with a thick mustache looks directly at the camera, a skull-like object is to the left of him; four children sit together on some steps; a young girl rides a rocking horse. The film roll ends, leading into an orange burst and then beam of light that perhaps represents the light needed to expose the film. The light beam is surrounded by black, blue, and gray clouds.

mods.abstract: Two smiling hispanic woman are depicted in this monochromatic mural installed by Dr. Chip Thomas during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. On the left, an older woman rests her head on the shoulder of a younger woman with her right hand raised to and resting on the right side of her face. On the older woman's cheek are the words "We Are Powerful" and on the left side of the younger woman's face, on her eyelid and cheek, are the words "No Somos Cien Somos Milliones Cuentanos Bien (We are not one. We Are not hundreds. We are millions. Count us well." The mural gestures towards the presence and vital role of the hispanic community in the U.S.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a trout with vibrantly colored, checkered skin. Among the various patterns in its checkered skin are cherries, PacMan ghosts, chains, peacock feathers, roses, polka dots, and botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern). Below the fish is the message "Lahontan Cutthroat Trout Back From Extinction!" A bee (not visible) hovers behind the trout, holding in its legs a sewing needle through which a piece of pink thread attached to the caudal peduncle of the fish is threaded. To the right of the bee are the words "One Love" and the artist's moniker (Mafat) and date.

record.Title: Unknown [Lahontan Cutthroat Back From Extinction!]

mods.abstract: The two roller doors of the Reno Fire Department station in downtown Reno each depict different fire helmets. On the left door is a dark-brown leather helmet with a red leather shield affixed to the front that reads "RFD 1 Engine." Smoke emerges from behind the helmet. In the lower-left corner of the door is a monochromatic scene depicting three firefighters and a fire engine. On the right third of the door is another monochromatic scene depicting one of two firefighters (or one split in half by the wall between the two doors) fully suited up and wearing a helmet with respirator.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock combines United States history with the history of Nevada in this mural that was commissioned to celebrate the Historic Lincoln Highway. Abraham Lincoln appears on the left side of the mural, leading to the Nevada flag and then U.S. flag, over which the words "LINCOLN HIGHWAY" are painted in different font styles and are flanked by the Nevada flag and the Interstate 40 highway sign. All subjects combined, this mural conveys the relevance of this president and his namesake highway.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock pays homage to the renowned artist, Georgia O'Keefe, through a surrealist-style head (that of O'Keefe, according to Rock) that explodes with ideas. The mountain on her left shoulder, as well as the hanging flower, refer subjects in O'Keefe's own artworks. Rock adds a twist to the O'Keefe style by incorporating words in different font styles and vibrant colors such as pink, purple, green, and yellow.

mods.abstract: According to artist Joe C. Rock, his mural on the exterior wall of the Renaissance Reno Downtown Hotel "depicts imagery of Reno and the greater-Nevada area. The octagon 'R' is from the second Reno arch that ran from 1963-1987 [and] the background is filled with sage, our state flower. The 'E' is filled with a mountain bluebird, our state bird. The 'N' is inside a silver state of Nevada with a portrait of Jesse Reno, our city's namesake. The 'O' is from the current Reno arch [and sits over] a heart, inside the 'O' is a landscape of Mt. Rose surrounded by a red rose. The piece is finished off with the words 'Home Means Nevada,' our state song" (https://www.instagram.com/p/BUS8FaqDbF4/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13).

record.Title: Reno

mods.abstract: This signal box is covered in white birch trees. Artist Clarissa Stephens painted the birches, with their characteristic white bark marked with long, horizontal lenticels (lines), against a background of nearly the same color, using a slightly more gray tone of white and a shading technique to make the birches pop against the white background. A few golden-yellow leaves appear on the tips of some of the birches' branches.

mods.abstract: Artist Stephane Cellier used the natural angles of the wall upon which he painted this monochromatic mural during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 to create an optical illusion. An "x" accompanied by "please stand here to view the mural" is painted on the the ground, marking the "sweet spot" from where the intended depiction of the mural can be correctly and fully observed (essentially from where this photograph was taken): a man receiving a kiss on the cheek from a woman with words above that read "Two Smiles Getting Closer End Up Making...A Kiss." Viewed head-on, the mural is a distorted mess.

record.Title: Unknown [Two Smiles Getting Closer End Up Making...A Kiss]

Viewed head-on, the mural is a distorted mess.

mods.abstract: A portion of the front end of a red classic car appears on the right side of Vaka's signal-box mural. Yellow and light-purple hand prints adorn the grill of the car and yellow, light-purple and light-blue hand prints appear below the bumper. A black mountainous skyline with "Reno" painted over it in pink is depicted in the car's license. Vaka's moniker is painted on the top of the right side in purple and white. The content and theme of the mural (the classic car and Monroe eating a burger) relates to the location in which the signal box resides: in front of Juicy's Giant Hamburgers, a popular restaurant in Reno with the feel of an old-fashioned burger joint.

mods.abstract: This mural is a three-part piece painted by artist Joe C. Rock. The two fences here (of three total) converge into a nautical star with monochromatic portraits of Jesse Lee Reno to the left and John Sparks to the right. (The right portion of the fence, portraying Sparks, has been torn down). Sage brush grows horizontally from each man's face. On the left (Reno) side of the fence, Nevada's nickname/slogan "Battle Born" is painted in black along the length of the fence, against a rich blue background. A mountain bluebird perches on the sagebrush in front of the "B" in "Born." The golden-yellow banner from the Nevada state flag wraps around flows through the entire scene. On the far right-end of the right (Sparks) side of the fence is a depiction of the Nevada bicentennial coin. Barbed wire winds around the sagebrush on this side of the fence, and the golden-yellow banner from the Nevada state flag wraps around flows through the entire scene.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.

A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.

mods.abstract: This mural painted by artist Joe C. Rock represents the city of Reno, as well as the Statewide Lighting & Accents company (where the mural resides). The center of the mural highlights a large brightly-lit light bulb with a crown (a common object in Rock's paintings) sitting at the top. Behind the light bulb, the city's well-known "Reno" sign hides, acknowledging the brightness of the rising city. The word "BRIGHT" is also woven within the mural behind leaves and orange circles. Underneath the light bulb, the ground from which the bulb rises is visible; the word "IDEAS" is written through a depiction of stones.

mods.abstract: Artist Stephane Cellier used the natural angles of the wall upon which he painted this monochromatic mural during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 to create an optical illusion. An "x" accompanied by "please stand here to view the mural" is painted on the the ground, marking the "sweet spot" from where the intended depiction of the mural can be correctly and fully observed (essentially from where this photograph was taken): a man receiving a kiss on the cheek from a woman with words above that read "Two Smiles Getting Closer End Up Making...A Kiss." Viewed head-on, the mural is a distorted mess.

mods.abstract: A rendering of Marilyn Monroe eating a burger wraps around the left and back side of Vaka's signal-box mural. Monroe wears a pink top and lifts the burger up to her mouth, ready to take a bight. A salt shaker sits in the lower-left corner of the back side of the box. The content and theme of the mural (the classic car and Monroe eating a burger) relates to the location in which the signal box resides: in front of Juicy's Giant Hamburgers, a popular restaurant in Reno with the feel of an old-fashioned burger joint.

On the right side, a little girl wearing a tutu has been painted against a vibrant yellow background using white, black, and blue paint and a stencil (a technique that Chisholm is known for). She casts a purple, water-coloresque shadow on the ground. Two tall buildings and a black human figure either jumping or striking a dance pose, (both also painted using a stencil), appear in the background.

mods.abstract: Artist Michael Lucido's electric-box mural depicts a food truck driven and manned by raccoons serving skateboards. The raccoon driving the truck wears sunglasses, his mouth is open with his tongue hanging out, his right arm hangs out the open window of the truck, and is raised up in the air with a "sign of the horns" gesture (the index finger and the little finger are upright and the thumb is clasped against the two middle fingers) on his hand. Another sunglass-wearing raccoon with a big-open smile on his face sits on the serving counter of the truck under a brown awning with his right foot resting on the back of a skateboard. His right hand flashes the "shaka" sign, also known as the "hang loose" sign, while he holds a red beverage in his left hand. Behind this raccoon, inside the truck, hang two rows of four vibrantly-colored skateboards. A fire-extinguisher cabinet with the message "In Case of Emergency Event Break Glass" painted on it hangs behind the raccoon that sits on the counter, but instead of containing a fire extinguisher, it contains an aqua-blue skateboard with pink wheels. The truck's license plate reads "RAD THF," a reference to the name of Lucido's clothing company: Rad Thief. The skateboard-food-truck theme of this box possibly relates to its location at City Park Plaza, used in the past as an unofficial skate park, and to the food-truck culture that has developed in the area over the past several years.

record.Title: Unknown [Raccoon Food Truck]

Another sunglass-wearing raccoon with a big-open smile on his face sits on the serving counter of the truck under a brown awning with his right foot resting on the back of a skateboard. His right hand flashes the "shaka" sign, also known as the "hang loose" sign, while he holds a red beverage in his left hand. Behind this raccoon, inside the truck, hang two rows of four vibrantly-colored skateboards. A fire-extinguisher cabinet with the message "In Case of Emergency Event Break Glass" painted on it hangs behind the raccoon that sits on the counter, but instead of containing a fire extinguisher, it contains an aqua-blue skateboard with pink wheels. The truck's license plate reads "RAD THF," a reference to the name of Lucido's clothing company: Rad Thief. The skateboard-food-truck theme of this box possibly relates to its location at City Park Plaza, used in the past as an unofficial skate park, and to the food-truck culture that has developed in the area over the past several years.

mods.abstract: Erik Burke painted this mural for Morgan's Lobster Shack and Fish Market, explaining the lobster in the middle of the mural against a background of blue ocean water that transitions to dark and then a lighter gray above, with nine buoys floating at the top of the mural. The buoys are painted a variety of colors (from left to right): white on a black rope; gold on a natural rope; black, yellow, and robin's-egg-blue striped on a black rope; red on a natural rope; pink on a natural rope; teal, white and red on a natural rope; pink on a natural rope; white and dark purple striped on a black rope; and black, white and red striped on a black rope. The lobster has been painted using several shades of orange and black, but the details of and sheen on the lobster was created using a variety of unexpected colors: sky, cerulean and periwinkle blue; yellow; peach; fern and crocodile green; lavender and iris purple; and red. Burke's moniker (OU38) and website (eriktburke.com) are painted in light blue on the bottom-left corner. The mural is 24 x 44 ft.

mods.abstract: Artist Michael Lucido's electric-box mural depicts a food truck driven and manned by raccoons serving skateboards. The raccoon driving the truck wears sunglasses, his mouth is open with his tongue hanging out, his right arm hangs out the open window of the truck, and is raised up in the air with a "sign of the horns" gesture (the index finger and the little finger are upright and the thumb is clasped against the two middle fingers) on his hand. Another sunglass-wearing raccoon with a big-open smile on his face sits on the serving counter of the truck under a brown awning with his right foot resting on the back of a skateboard. His right hand flashes the "shaka" sign, also known as the "hang loose" sign, while he holds a red beverage in his left hand. Behind this raccoon, inside the truck, hang two rows of four vibrantly-colored skateboards. A fire-extinguisher cabinet with the message "In Case of Emergency Event Break Glass" painted on it hangs behind the raccoon that sits on the counter, but instead of containing a fire extinguisher, it contains an aqua-blue skateboard with pink wheels. The skateboard-food-truck theme of this box possibly relates to its location at City Park Plaza, used in the past as an unofficial skate park, and to the food-truck culture that has developed in the area over the past several years.

mods.abstract: In this mural painted on a warehouse on Dickerson Road, artist Anthony Ortega stays true to his style and paints an intergalactic mural. Amidst the black and purple background emerges an array of alien scenes. On the right, a man enters (or exits) a green-lit hallway, next to him enters a UFO occupied with visitors from another world or galaxy. Underneath the UFO, someone is being abducted by another UFO at the top of the mural, further reinforced by how its green rays morph the individual's skin to an alien-like green color.

mods.abstract: This mural painted by artist Erik Burke embraces the history of Nevada. Similar to his other murals, this work is composed of two main elements: a landscape, and the words "GO WEST." The landscape depicts the variety of mountain ranges in Nevada, suggested by the variety of color (shades of red and blue) in which they are painted. The landscape also portrays a wild mustang, an animal representative of the "wild west" nature of Nevada. On the right side of the mural appears a female figure holding a lantern, as if guiding the horse and throwing into relief the words "GO WEST." The words are painted in a subtle yellow and white that merges them into the landscape. The lines in between the words, which depict birch trees with Basque tree carvings that are found in the state, weave in front of and behind the mustang and run parallel (and in some cases line up directly with) the building behind the mural (the Silver Legacy Hotel & Casino), further connecting the mural to the city.

mods.abstract: The mural on the left, painted by HS, combines graffiti with vibrant animation. Silly monkeys and a cockatoo perched on a branch flank the vibrant graffiti text that emerges from green leaves. The mural on the right, painted by members of UTI Crew, depicts imagery associated with heavy metal band Iron Maiden. The mummy, skeletons, graveyard, and ominous skylines can all be found on various album covers and merchandise. Various graffiti-style words (likely the artists' monikers) appear throughout the mural.

mods.abstract: Each side of Bryce Chisholm's signal box portrays a distinct image. On the front, a young girl wearing a floral headpiece sits on the ground and looks down happily at something she holds in her left hand. The girl was painted against a vibrant yellow background using black, white, and blue paint and a stencil (a technique Chisholm is known for). A teal and lavender hummingbird (also painted using a stencil) silhouetted in magenta and aqua blue hovers behind and to the left of the girl, and the sun sitting behind the girl casts heather-purple rays. Three white damask patterns have been painted in succession (using stencil) on the right side of the box, and a geometric pattern has been painted in magenta in the upper-left corner of the box.

mods.abstract: The back side of Cathy Ashworth's signal-box mural colorfully portrays Nevada pride. In the center of the box is a heart with a crown in a traditional-tattoo style. A white banner covers the inside of the heart and reads "Battle Born," Nevada's motto. A blue crown is placed on top of the heart and flames arise from it. Surrounding the heart are thick lines in different colors.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock pays homage to the renowned artist, Georgia O'Keefe, through a surrealist-style head (that of O'Keefe, according to Rock) that explodes with ideas. The mountain on her left shoulder, as well as the hanging flower, refer subjects in O'Keefe's own artworks. Rock adds a twist to the O'Keefe style by incorporating words in different font styles and vibrant colors such as pink, purple, green, and yellow.

mods.abstract: The scholastic theme of this mural by artist Joe C. Rock relates to its location on a wall of the building that used to house the Rainshadow Community Charter High School. The boy, who wears a tan hat and matching shirt with the the Rolling Stones iconic lips and tongue logo on it, carries graded assignments and a copy of Tolstoy's War and Peace in his left arm as he and his dog (with a crown floating above its head: a common object in Rock's murals) run through the tall trees. Books, one open with a house emerging from its pages, float around the boy, perhaps they have flown out of his blue backpack. A red bird perches on a tree branch behind the boy and three lady bugs fly around the bottom of the mural, two behind the dog and one by the boy's right foot.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.abstract: The mural on the two adjacent back walls of Mountain Music Parlor was painted by a group of youth who are part of the Children's Cabinet's "Spray Positive" program. This program was instigated by the Reno Police Department, in collaboration with the Children's Cabinet, as a way to beautify blighted properties in Midtown and Downtown Reno. A dream catcher with music notes in the web leads to the head of a Native-American figure wearing an elaborate headdress. An American flag emerges from the left side of the headdress and straddles both walls. A portrait of a man in a cowboy hat (most likely bluegrass musician Bill Monroe) painted in front of the flag graces the adjacent wall, and the mural concludes with a rendering of a chick playing a cello with the name "Bill Monroe" painted above it.

The shapes and colors from the background wrap around the entire box.

mods.abstract: The mural on the left depicts two portraits of female faces along with other figures and patterns. The woman painted in shades of red and pink looks down while the woman painted in blue stares as if looking ahead. To the left side of the blue woman, a pink animated figure seems to combine elements of the human face and a cat. It emerges from the bottom of the wall and becomes more enlarged as it reaches the top of the mural. It has a fierce face, depicted by the stern four eyes and the showing of its teeth. In the mural on the far right, Anthony Ortega stays true to his style and paints an intergalactic mural. Amidst the black and purple background emerges an array of alien scenes. On the right, a man enters (or exits) a green-lit hallway, next to him enters a UFO occupied with visitors from another world or galaxy. Underneath the UFO, someone is being abducted by another UFO at the top of the mural, further reinforced by how its green rays morph the individual's skin to an alien-like green color. In the middle of the mural appears another green woman making a phone call, while a city rests above her. Lastly, on the left side resides an eerie church with the words "THEY LIVE" appearing above the church.

mods.abstract: Anthony Ortega won the 2017 24-Hour Mural Marathon competition with a psychedelic mural composition that combines ancient Mesoamerican art with futuristic elements. This mural is painted with vibrant shades of blue, red, green, orange, yellow, pink, and purple, portraying a vivid ancient Mesoamerican god-like figure that emerges from the stellar depths of the galaxy behind it and begins its descent into the green forest that surrounds the outer edges of the mural.

mods.abstract: Visionary, painted by Erik Burke, focuses on the bright and deep-blue eyes of what appears to be a female, looking up in wonder, imagination, or inquiry, as the mural's title suggests. Set against a light blue background, Burke utilized the natural color of the brick wall to represent the figure's skin tone. The mural is painted using a simple color palette of red, orange, brown, and a few different shades of blue, as well as black for the eyelashes and brows. Burke tied the red, orange, brown and blue into the geometric pattern painted on the sliding door that sits in the center of the wall/mural.

mods.abstract: This signal box was painted by artist Michael Lucido to look like it has been boarded up and turned into a raccoon fort, as the mural's title suggests. On the left side of the box, a wide-eyed raccoon leaning back with its mouth wide open about to devour a piece of pepperoni pizza peaks out through an opening in the boards. Its tail pokes out through an opening between the boards. Below this, the words "Insert Food" and arrows, both painted red, surround and point to another opening between the boards.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a large brown octopus mixed with peacock feathers and a human-like figure. The octopus is the focus of the mural. The body of the octopus is painted in a palette of browns, while its suckers are painted in a palette of blue. The peacock feathers almost resemble the suckers as they intertwine into the octopus's tentacles. The tentacles wrap around and burst through a portrait of a blue human-like figure wearing headphones that emerges from the mud-cracked ground, perhaps representing Burning Man since the business upon which the mural is painted, The Melting Pot World Emporium, is one of the leading retailers of Playa gear in the area. The figure stares out into the distance. A tentacle bursts through the middle portrait, which depicts the Burning Man logo centered in the Burning-Man-Playa landscape with planets hanging in the night sky above. The last portrait is a circus-style wall sign for the The Melting Pot. A curtain opens up to a stage with silhouettes of people dancing in front of an earth with sun rays around it. The background of the entire mural is painted a bright red, contrasting the aquatic and desert ambiance of the subject matter.

mods.abstract: This 65 x (roughly) 16 foot mural pinated on the wall of Peerless Cleaners by artist Erik Burke combines Reno history and Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is speckled with small symbols that depict prominent Reno figures, organizations, and locations in the business's and city's history. Some of these symbols are connected, like constellations, by a line that carries throughout the composition. The mountain-range landscape can also be interpreted as draped fabric, connecting the mural to the the business located in that building. The mural is painted in shades of red, orange, yellow, blue and white.

mods.abstract: Artist Stephane Cellier used the natural angles of the wall upon which he painted this monochromatic mural during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 to create an optical illusion. An "x" accompanied by "please stand here to view the mural" is painted on the the ground, marking the "sweet spot" from where the intended depiction of the mural can be correctly and fully observed: a man receiving a kiss on the cheek from a woman with words above that read "Two Smiles Getting Closer End Up Making...A Kiss." Viewed head-on, the mural is a distorted mess.

mods.abstract: A rendering of Marilyn Monroe eating a burger appears on the back side of Vaka's signal-box mural. Monroe lifts the burger up to her mouth, ready to take a bight. A salt shaker sits in the lower-left corner. The content and theme of the mural (the classic car and Monroe eating a burger) relates to the location in which the signal box resides: in front of Juicy's Giant Hamburgers, a popular restaurant in Reno with the feel of an old-fashioned burger joint.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock combines United States history with the history of Nevada in this mural that was commissioned to celebrate the Historic Lincoln Highway. Abraham Lincoln appears on the left side of the mural, leading to the Nevada flag and then U.S. flag, over which the words "LINCOLN HIGHWAY" are painted in different font styles and are flanked by the Nevada flag and the Interstate 40 highway sign. All subjects combined, this mural conveys the relevance of this president and his namesake highway.

mods.abstract: The left side of Michael Lucido's electric-box mural is painted black with the words "Reno Is Rad." All three words have a different appearance: "Reno" is all caps, painted in aqua-blue block letters with magenta shadows; "Is" appears in black caps against a bright yellow banner-like background; "Rad" is painted in white cursive letters, with a white underline. White eight-pointed stars speckle the panel.

mods.abstract: This wall on the west side of the building occupied by Nevada Fine Arts contains six 16 x 20 ft. panels, each painted by a different artist. From left to right: Artist Joe C. Rock pays homage to the renowned artist, Georgia O'Keefe, through a surrealist-style head (that of O'Keefe, according to Rock) that explodes with ideas. The mountain on her left shoulder, as well as the hanging flower, refer subjects in O'Keefe's own artworks. Rock adds a twist to the O'Keefe style by incorporating words in different font styles and vibrant colors such as pink, purple, green, and yellow; Artist Nanook portrays hands emerging from a turquoise background balancing stones. A blue and green ikat patterned snake-like object winds through the mural, separating the turquoise background from the abstract blue sky above; Erik Burke describes his mural, Rebuilding the Block, as "a texture dense field of western motifs and a deconstructed cinder block. Atop the pattern sits yellow lines demarcating the layout of the streets, a mile in every direction. A pair of eyes represent the creative visionaries atop a city determined to reinvent itself without any luck or success. The nearby peak of Mt. Rose is anchored at the base of the wall, covering the mouth and serving as a reference point for Reno's most regarded resource...Lake Tahoe" (eriktburke.com). A gray cinder block floats in front of a person's forehead, framed by hair. Piercing blue eyes stare at the viewer as the facial features begin to fade at the bridge of the nose. Blue, green, and red triangles in ones, twos, and threes speckle the mural and comprise Lake Tahoe at the bottom of the mural, with Mt. Rose rising above. Faint yellow lines representing roads/streets cover the mural.

mods.abstract: Artist Michael Lucido's electric-box mural depicts a food truck driven and manned by raccoons serving skateboards. The raccoon driving the truck wears sunglasses, his mouth is open with his tongue hanging out, his right arm hangs out the open window of the truck, and is raised up in the air with a "sign of the horns" gesture (the index finger and the little finger are upright and the thumb is clasped against the two middle fingers) on his hand. Another sunglass-wearing raccoon with a big-open smile on his face sits on the serving counter of the truck under a brown awning with his right foot resting on the back of a skateboard. His right hand flashes the "shaka" sign, also known as the "hang loose" sign, while he holds a red beverage in his left hand. Behind this raccoon, inside the truck, hang two rows of four vibrantly-colored skateboards. A fire-extinguisher cabinet with the message "In Case of Emergency Event Break Glass" painted on it hangs behind the raccoon that sits on the counter, but instead of containing a fire extinguisher, it contains an aqua-blue skateboard with pink wheels. The skateboard-food-truck theme of this box possibly relates to its location at City Park Plaza, used in the past as an unofficial skate park, and to the food-truck culture that has developed in the area over the past several years.

mods.abstract: In this collaborative piece painted by Erik Burke, Kelly Peyton, and Kaitlyn Bryson, a male figure wearing dark blue jeans and a yellow tank top lays on his back in front of a blue background with hands interlaced and resting on his stomach. It appears as though the man is floating. In the bottom-left corner of the mural, circular, triangular, other geometric shapes, and dashes are painted on the man's pants in a shade of blue lighter than the pants and more like that of the background. Similar shapes are painted in marigold yellow on the man's shirt, as are figures fashioned out of the letters "L" and "D" and the number "4" (L4, D4); these figures represent the phrase "Live for What You Would Die For." These figures, and the phrase they represent, likely relate to the theme and purpose of the mural, referred to by one if its painters, Burke, as a tribute to Beau Shaver of Reno, NV who is also likely the man depicted in the mural. The man also has various shapes (hearts, roses, the outline of a crown) and words painted in yellow on his arm, neck, face and teeth. The background of the right side of the mural is painted in graduated shades of blue (light to dark, from the bottom to the top). An upside down brown hat appears in the lower-right corner of the mural, it has currant-red-outlined-in-yellow flowers sitting on the brim and one flower peaking out from inside. Burke's moniker (OU33), the other two artists' initials (KP and Kb), and the date (2012) are painted in white in the upper-right corner of the mural, with "L4D4 SODC SHAVER" painted below. The mural is 80 x 16 ft.

mods.abstract: This candy- and dessert-themed mural was painted by artist Joe C. Rock for Sierra Nevada Chocolate. Chocolate-covered strawberries and various chocolate treats are depicted at the bottom of the mural. A banana wearing a top hat and bowtie walks on the left side of the mural, chocolate is stuck to the bottom of its shoe. The business's name is painted in brown with mint green outline in the middle of the mural and is flanked on the left by a spoon with chocolate dripping from its bowl and an ice-cream sundae, and on the right by another chocolaty spoon and two chocolate covered strawberries, one decorated with a white-chocolate dress and pearls and the other with a white-and dark-chocolate tuxedo.

mods.abstract: A musician holding a guitar and singing into a microphone painted against a slate-blue background is the apt focal point of this mural painted on the Studio on 4th: "an eclectic art venue with a stage, seating with cocktail tables, and a full bar" (https://www.facebook.com/pg/StudioOn4thReno/about/?ref=page_internal). White music notes float around the musician, near where his guitar rests. A hand with the "sign of the horns" gesture on it rises from the bottom of the mural, beside it, the word "Rock" is painted in black within a white text bubble. Peach and green geometric shapes overlapping each other are painted on the lower half of the left side of the mural.

record.Title: Unknown [Musician Performing]
record.Description: A musician holding a guitar and singing into a microphone painted against a slate-blue background is the apt focal point of this mural painted on the Studio on 4th: "an eclectic art venue with a stage, seating with cocktail tables, and a full bar" (https://www.facebook.com/pg/StudioOn4thReno/about/?ref=page_internal). White music notes float around the musician, near where his guitar rests. A hand with the "sign of the horns" gesture on it rises from the bottom of the mural, beside it, the word "Rock" is painted in black within a white text bubble. Peach and green geometric shapes overlapping each other are painted on the lower half of the left side of the mural.
record.Sitelocation: Western wall of Studio on 4th Bar and Venue at 432 E. 4th St., Reno, NV

subject.geographic: Roller doors on the Reno Fire Department at 495 E. 4th St., Reno, NV

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. mods.abstract: The two roller doors of the Reno Fire Department station in downtown Reno each depict different fire helmets: on the left is a dark-brown leather helmet with a red leather shield affixed to the front that reads "RFD 1 Engine;" on the right, a black leather (likely) helmet with a brass eagle adornment affixed to the top of the helmet to secure a leather shield that reads "Reno Fire Firefighter Truck 1" to the front helmet front. The crown (an object that appears in many of Rock's murals) on the eagle's head is not found on actual helmets. Smoke emerges from behind both helmets. In the lower-left side of the left door is a monochromatic scene depicting three firefighters and a fire engine. In lower-right side of the right door is a monochromatic scene depicting a firefighter manning the deluge gun on top of a fire engine. On the right third of the left door and the left third of the right door is another monochromatic scene depicting two firefighters (or one split in half by the wall between the two doors) fully suited up and wearing a helmet with respirator, while three people climb a ladder in the background to the right.

mods.abstract: This mural is composed by several artists, Joe C. Rock and Jennifer Charboneau among them. The left-hand side, painted by G. Orlandoyack, consists of vibrant pinks and blues with female-looking subjects. The middle, painted by Rock, features a woman's face partially covered by a fan, behind which the face takes on the appearance of a Day of the Day skull. The mural is composed using black, white, gray and shades of blue. The right side, painted by Charboneau, consists of a darker palette with a more abstract expressionist brushstroke and depicts an idle woman wearing a red shirt, blue skirt, and heels sitting at a bar having a drink. The only other recognizable object is the table adjacent to the woman.

mods.abstract: Devin Hosselkus' signal-box mural depicts various individuals in a city-like setting (perhaps downtown Reno, given the location of the box just north of the Virginia Street Bridge over the Truckee River). In the foreground of the front side of the box is the profile of a person with gray hair and purple skin, wearing a green shirt and brown paints, apparently walking towards the left. In the background and what appears to be across the street, from left to right: a person wearing a white shirt and blue pants sits on a wooden bench in a front of a brick building; a man wearing a white tank tops looks across the street; a man with blue skin, wearing a white shirt and brown pants walks towards the left; a person wearing a maroon shirt walks in the opposite direction; a person wearing a white bandana, black shirt and gray pants has their back turned away from the viewer. A body of water (presumably the Truckee River) flows under a bridge and street lights behind and to the right of the person in the foreground.

mods.abstract: These five murals are painted on garage doors along the back exterior wall of the West Street Market. From left to right: A crowned bird spreading its multicolored wings is the focal point of this mural. A large egg-like object sits in front of the bird who has perhaps laid it; The second mural depicts a bright blue elephant with white tusks and a bright-pink-tipped trunk wearing a gray hat, thick-rimmed glasses, and a gold chain with a "B" pendant swinging from it; In the third mural, a purple bird and blue-skinned woman, both wearing headdresses, face each other against a kelly-green background with a lighter green and yellow design in the middle; In the fourth mural, swirly abstract clouds or bubbles float in front of a sun with lime-green swirly lines over a dark-green background exposed between its rays; The fifth (last) mural depicts a purple-skinned girl with short dark hair, wearing a pink and white dress, holding onto to strings attached to two red balloons.

mods.abstract: This hardware-themed mural was painted by artist Joe C. Rock on the southern wall of Ace Hardware in Midtown Reno. On the left side of the mural, a can of red paint pours down from the top onto a wooden paint stirrer stick with the Ace logo on it. On the left, a paint brush has been dipped in the red paint and a paint roller above the brush has been rolled in the paint. In the scene on the right side of the mural, a man wearing a white chef's hat and apron is barbecuing or deep frying a turkey in a fenced-in yard surrounded by tall pine trees. Rock has utilized the natural brick facade of the wall to depict the brick patio the man stands on, and the blue sky behind and above him flows into the blue label on the paint can.

mods.abstract: This signal box was painted by artist Michael Lucido to look like it has been boarded up and turned into a raccoon fort, as the mural's title suggests. On the front side of the box, a wide-eyed raccoon with its mouth wide open peaks out through an opening between the boards, a bare fish skeleton dangles from its left paw, its tail pokes out through a hole in a board. The words "Raccoons Only" appear in red below the raccoon, and Lucido's last name, website (www.thatlucidokid.com) and the date are painted in black at the very bottom of the box. On the right side of the box, a wide-eyed raccoon with its mouth wide open stands outside the fort with a Campbell's Tomato Soup can in its left paw and a paint brush in its right paw. Red tomato soup is on the tip of the brush, as well as on the raccoon's tongue and around its mouth. The words "Rad City" are painted in red on a board above the raccoon's head.

mods.abstract: This under-the-sea-themed mural was painted by artist Vaka on the exterior of Stingray Tattoo, where he works as a tattoo artist. Several dark blue stingrays swim throughout the mural that wraps around two adjacent walls on the northeast side of the tattoo parlor, covers the ceiling that overhangs the walls and spills into the pavement below. Two orange, white and black clown fish swim through some purple sea anemones and and light blue sponges that emerge from the bottom corner of the mural where the two walls meet. On the far right side (northern wall) of the mural, a massive ray swims towards some red coral that flanks a window. On the left side (eastern wall) of the mural, a word (possibly "Ink") is painted red and white in flourish font, while the same paint colors are used on the cinderblocks of the wall to create the illusion that the wall is breaking and falling into the sea; several of these broken blocks float throughout the mural.

mods.abstract: Artists Nanook paints a bull with rooster-patterned fur against a white background with a dark aegean-blue border at the bottom. Three large black circles with mustard-yellow outlines and flowers with dark-red centers speckle the mural and one large red circle appears in the center of the mural. A prominent cerulean-blue curvy line with a lighter and thinner line next to it horizontally spans the mural, weaving through and around the circles and bull. In the bottom left corner of the mural, Nanook's moniker and the date have been painted in the same blue as the curvy line against the dark aegean-blue border.

mods.abstract: Each side of Bryce Chisholm's signal box portrays a distinct image. On the back side, a young woman has been painted in yellow, black, and white using a stencil (a technique Chisholm is known for). Two horse heads have been paint behind the woman with the same colors and technique. Between the horses, two damask patterns have been painted in white (using a stencil) against a light purple background. Two larger damask patterns have been painted (with stencil) against a turquoise background to the left of the girl. The letters "NV"(Nevada's abbreviation) are painted in teal below the woman and Chisholm's moniker (ABC Art Attack) appears in black to the right.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a large brown octopus mixed with peacock feathers and a human-like figure. The octopus is the focus of the mural. The body of the octopus is painted in a palette of browns, while its suckers are painted in a palette of blue. The peacock feathers almost resemble the suckers as they intertwine into the octopus's tentacles. The tentacles wrap around and burst through a portrait of a blue human-like figure wearing headphones that emerges from the mud-cracked ground, perhaps representing Burning Man since the business upon which the mural is painted, The Melting Pot World Emporium, is one of the leading retailers of Playa gear in the area. The figure stares out into the distance. A tentacle bursts through the middle portrait, which depicts the Burning Man logo centered in the Burning-Man-Playa landscape with planets hanging in the night sky above. The last portrait is a circus-style wall sign for the The Melting Pot. A curtain opens up to a stage with silhouettes of people dancing in front of an earth with sun rays around it. The background of the entire mural is painted a bright red, contrasting the aquatic and desert ambiance of the subject matter.

mods.abstract: As its name suggest, this mural by artist Joe C. Rock depicts a man daydreaming as he lays (or floats) on his back in (or above) the grass underneath a sky populated by white-puffy clouds. A butterfly perches on his Davey-Crockett-coonskin hat that floats away from his head, which has another butterfly perched on it with another butterfly flying slightly above it. A lit cigarette floats away from his mouth, and a bluebird perches on his blue jacket that has the Nevada state seal on the upper right arm. A raccoon crawls between the man's lower legs towards a black book with a blue and white "Hello My Name Is" name tag on it; "Joe C." is written on the name tag. The book is attached to a line that wraps around the man's left leg and has a hook with a worm attached that dangles in front of the bluebird. A tiny pair of eyeglasses floats between the worm and bird. To the right of the book, a marmot-like animal with a crown (a common object in Rock's murals) floating above its head stands on its hind legs in the grass facing towards to man. Behind the animal, in the distance, there is a green house with power lines suspended on poles overhead.

mods.abstract: According to artist Erik Burke who painted this 18 x 50 foot mural, "The Hudson Project is a block of mixed-use urban infill development between Center and Lake Street on State Street. The mural graces the east side of the development and is a visualization of all the people and business that inhabited this block dating back to 1890" (http://eriktburke.com/Hudson-Project). The upper portion of the left side of the mural is composed of various vibrant shades of green while the bottom portion depicting a landscape is composed of a vibrant blue, brown/tan, yellow, and more green. The right side of the mural is a wheat pasted silhouette profile of a man conducting a land survey against a large white circle (perhaps representing the moon). This technique creates a life-like, almost 3D depiction of the man, the colors of which tie in with the left portion of the mural.

mods.abstract: A red classic car with a white roof wraps around the front and right side of Vaka's signal-box mural. Yellow and light-purple hand prints adorn the grill of the car and yellow, light-purple and light-blue hand prints appear below the bumper. A black mountainous skyline with "Reno" painted over it in pink is depicted in the car's license plate. Vaka's moniker is painted on the top of the right side in purple and white. The content and theme of the mural (the classic car and Monroe eating a burger) relates to the location in which the signal box resides: in front of Juicy's Giant Hamburgers, a popular restaurant in Reno with the feel of an old-fashioned burger joint.

mods.abstract: Five panels of this wall were painted by five different artists during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. The three here are by artists Emily Reid, Lisa Kurt and Joshua Coffy. Reid depicts a cow in her mural. Reid paints the background shades of green and blue and the cow is outlined over these colors. Kurt paints a black fox standing in a meadow within a forest landscape. Surrounding the fox are trees, bushes, tumbleweed and a ghost. Kurt uses yellow, orange, green, black, and white to paint this mural. Coffy's mural features a black bear with ryukin goldfish swimming around it. The bottom third of the mural's background is an aegean-blue color, perhaps representative of water, while the rest of the background is tan with chiffon circles (or bubbles). A grid of eleven colors has been painted in the top middle of the mural.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.

mods.abstract: During the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, artist Ricky Lee Gordon painted a female figure with the word "NATURE" hovering over her. Gordon uses dark colors to obscure the woman's face. The woman represents the Native American community in northern Nevada and the importance of conserving nature. A message in the lower-right corner of the mural reads "Nature Conspires with Spirit to Emancipate Us."

mods.abstract: The front side of Cathy Ashworth's signal-box mural portrays Reno pride. In the center of the work lies a red heart with a banner across it that reads "Reno." Like the back of the box, fire also arises from the heart and the Burning Man logo appears in the main flame. The background is then divided into sections that depict scenery relating to northern Nevada.

mods.abstract: The mural on the two adjacent back walls of Mountain Music Parlor was painted by a group of youth who are part of the Children's Cabinet's "Spray Positive" program. This program was instigated by the Reno Police Department, in collaboration with the Children's Cabinet, as a way to beautify blighted properties in Midtown and Downtown Reno. A dream catcher with music notes in the web leads to the head of a Native-American figure wearing an elaborate headdress. An American flag emerges from the left side of the headdress and straddles both walls. A portrait of a man in a cowboy hat (most likely bluegrass musician Bill Monroe) painted in front of the flag graces the adjacent wall, and the mural concludes with a rendering of a chick playing a cello with the name "Bill Monroe" painted above it.

record.Title: Unknown [Dream Catcher, Native American in Head Dress, American Flag, Bill Monroe]
record.Description: The mural on the two adjacent back walls of Mountain Music Parlor was painted by a group of youth who are part of the Children's Cabinet's "Spray Positive" program. This program was instigated by the Reno Police Department, in collaboration with the Children's Cabinet, as a way to beautify blighted properties in Midtown and Downtown Reno. A dream catcher with music notes in the web leads to the head of a Native-American figure wearing an elaborate headdress. An American flag emerges from the left side of the headdress and straddles both walls. A portrait of a man in a cowboy hat (most likely bluegrass musician Bill Monroe) painted in front of the flag graces the adjacent wall, and the mural concludes with a rendering of a chick playing a cello with the name "Bill Monroe" painted above it.
record.Sitelocation: Southern and western wall of Mountain Music Parlor at 735 S. Center St., Reno, NV

mods.abstract: These two murals are painted on garage doors along the back exterior wall of the West Street Market. On the left, sharp geometric mountains painted in rich shades or red, orange, and yellow against an aqua, turquoise and teal blue sky are the focal point of this mural. On the right, a big horn sheep gazes up towards the body of another sheep (or perhaps its own detached body). The figures are painted in red outline and shadowing agains a vibrant blue background. Bubbles emerge from the bottom of the mural and bright orange and green beams cast their color on the sheep head and body.

mods.abstract: In this mural painted on a warehouse on Dickerson Road, artist Anthony Ortega stays true to his style and paints an intergalactic mural. Amidst the black and purple background emerges an array of alien scenes. On the right, a man enters (or exits) a green-lit hallway, next to him enters a UFO occupied with visitors from another world or galaxy. Underneath the UFO, someone is being abducted by another UFO at the top of the mural, further reinforced by how its green rays morph the individual's skin to an alien-like green color. In the middle of the mural appears another green woman making a phone call, while a city rests above her. Lastly, on the left side resides an eerie church with the words "THEY LIVE" appearing above the church.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.abstract: Artist Kyler Martz painted this mural in a style reminiscent of American traditional tattoo during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. It depicts a tattoo-covered woman in a red swimsuit with white polka dots riding a trout on Lake Tahoe with the snow-peaked Sierras in the background. A cowboy hat is strapped around her neck and blowing behind her. This scene is flanked by two tattoo-covered women in white and gray (one striped, one with a fish-scale pattern) swimsuits riding sea horses and holding a tan banner that reads "Lake Tahoe 1959" over their heads with their free hands. The women have red bandanas around their necks, and the sea horses have red dorsal fins. A red banner that reads "Queen of the Rodeo" runs across the bottom of the mural.

mods.abstract: The theme of this vibrant mural, painted by members of UTI Crew during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, directly relates to the location in which it is painted: the wall of Headquarters Bar, a bar owned and operated by "Crawl Reno, the organizers of the Reno Zombie Crawl and a ton of other massive parties in downtown Reno" (http://headquartersreno.com/#home_about). On the right side of the mural stands a man with characteristics representative of the various crawls that take place in Reno throughout the year. The red Santa hat he wears with gold polka dots and a gold fur ball gestures towards the Santa Crawl; his green beard gestures towards the Leprechaun Crawl; and the Superman shirt he wears gestures towards the Super Hero Crawl. On the left side of the mural is a zombie with a mask resting on the top of its head, representing both the Zombie and Mardi Gras Crawls. These two figures flank four separate graffiti-style words (one of which appears to be the moniker of one of the UTI Crew members, Spek). In the background of the mural, a city skyline goes up in flames, perhaps caused by the man on the left who holds a lit match in his right hand, a mug of bear in his left. To the left of the mural is a small chain link fence with wood slats upon which "The Crawl" is painted in aqua, turquoise and sky blue horror font against a yellow and orange background with red splatters.

mods.abstract: This mural is a three-part piece painted by artist Joe C. Rock. The fence here (of three total) depicts a hand-drawn rudimentary map representing Sparks, Reno, Virginia City and Carson City, Nevada. The sage brush that grows horizontally behind the map peaks through holes in the map and the golden-yellow banner from the Nevada state flag wraps around and through the entire seen. A monochromatic portrait of Kit Carson is painted on the-right side of the fence.

mods.abstract: This panoramic photo captures most of the murals that grace the walls of what is known as "Taylor Alley." On the left, this graffiti mural by UTI Crew demonstrates the vast array of graffiti writing styles. The artists of these pieces use a bright palette and caricatures to heighten the visual element of the text. On the right, the mural on the far left, painted by HS, combines graffiti with vibrant animation. Silly monkeys and a cockatoo perched on a branch flank the vibrant graffiti text that emerges from green leaves. The mural to the right of this, painted by members of UTI Crew, depicts imagery associated with heavy metal band Iron Maiden. The mummy, skeletons, graveyard, and ominous skylines can all be found on various album covers and merchandise. Various graffiti-style words (likely the artists' monikers) appear throughout the mural.

record.Title: Unknown [Steam Punk Figures and the City]; Unknown [Monkeys, Leaves, and Birds]; Unknown [Iron Maiden Imagery: Mummy, Skeletons, Cemetery and Skyline]
record.Description: This panoramic photo captures most of the murals that grace the walls of what is known as "Taylor Alley." On the left, this graffiti mural by UTI Crew demonstrates the vast array of graffiti writing styles. The artists of these pieces use a bright palette and caricatures to heighten the visual element of the text. On the right, the mural on the far left, painted by HS, combines graffiti with vibrant animation. Silly monkeys and a cockatoo perched on a branch flank the vibrant graffiti text that emerges from green leaves. The mural to the right of this, painted by members of UTI Crew, depicts imagery associated with heavy metal band Iron Maiden. The mummy, skeletons, graveyard, and ominous skylines can all be found on various album covers and merchandise. Various graffiti-style words (likely the artists' monikers) appear throughout the mural.
record.Sitelocation: Southern wall of Best Value Inn (a.k.a. "Taylor Alley") at 844 S. Virginia St., Reno, NV and Northern wall of Lasting Does Tattoo (a.k.a. "Taylor Alley") at 888 S. Virginia St., Reno, NV

mods.abstract: This 65 x (roughly) 16 foot mural pinated on the wall of Peerless Cleaners by artist Erik Burke combines Reno history and Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is speckled with small symbols that depict prominent Reno figures, organizations, and locations in the business's and city's history. Some of these symbols are connected, like constellations, by a line that carries throughout the composition. The mountain-range landscape can also be interpreted as draped fabric, connecting the mural to the the business located in that building. The mural is painted in shades of red, orange, yellow, blue and white.

mods.abstract: "DAYDREAM!" appears in all caps in this mural that artist Joe C. Rock painted on a chain link fence with wood slats. Enclosed within the block letters is green grass against a blue skyline. The letters are outlined in white and cast red shadows outlined in peach. Growing out of the grass in the first "D" is a blue flower. A butterfly with blue wings perches on the outside edge of the second "D" and a lady bug crawls across the grass. A red rose rests on the left side of the "R." A worm slithers through the grass, straddling the right side of the "R" and left side of the "E," disappearing and re-emerging out of the right side of the "E." A blue flower with a lady bug on it grows out of the grass in the dot of the exclamation point.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural, originally painted for Lulu's Chic Boutique (now Timeless Fashion Consignment Shop and Bridal Salon) by artist Joe C. Rock, consists of a variety of geometric shapes, designs, patterns, and objects. The top portion of the mural is comprised of black polka dots. Water or mountains (what is actually the hair of a woman painted on the adjacent right or east-facing wall) flows from from the right, rising and then encircling the business logo painted in the center of the wall with the moon rising above it to the left. The logo is flanked on the left by the Eiffel Tower and on the right by the profile of a monocle-wearing man with a curly handlebar mustache whose top hat is the Leaning Tower of Pisa. Centered below the logo is an ornate fleurs-de-lis flanked by botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern). More fleurs-de-lis and botehs, as well as another top-hat-wearing figure, diamonds, various-sized squares, circles/dots, and flourish patterns speckle the left side of the mural. Rock brings a little color into the far-left side of the mural (under the window), where he has painted his moniker and some red dots (a few also appear to the left of and above the window).

mods.abstract: A fluid mural is painted by artist Joe C. Rock on this three-sided fence. The mural begins with the head of a woman in front of clouds whose hair then flows throughout the mural, as do the clouds. An array of subject matter appear among the hair and clouds over a light-blue background. While some figures portray recognizable figures, such as dice, eye balls, power lines, butterflies, rain drops, a bee, a rose, a mountain range, and botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern), other subjects and figures are more abstract, or focus on written text.
