mods.abstract: Ponderous, painted by Erik Burke on a metal meat freezer at Ponderosa Meat & Provision Co., features a portrait of John Muir on the left in front of snow-covered mountains and a body of water, flanked by an open hand about to receive a pine cone, with white and gray stripes running through the scene. Burke used a simple color palette consisting of white, black, grays and browns. The description of the mural on Burke's website is as follows: "Correlating the etymology of the building's namesake and John Muir, a profound advocate for the preservation and enjoyment of the nearby Sierras. The mural places a pondering and monochromatic Muir in a winter landscape next to a hand catching a falling pinecone as an allegory for the weight of man's relationship with nature. A trinity of lines helps order the various planes and build a stage of depth."

mods.abstract: Artist Kyler Martz painted this mural in a style reminiscent of American traditional tattoo during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. It depicts a tattoo-covered woman in a red swimsuit with white polka dots riding a trout on Lake Tahoe with the snow-peaked Sierras in the background. A cowboy hat is strapped around her neck and blowing behind her. This scene is flanked by two tattoo-covered women in white and gray (one striped, one with a fish-scale pattern) swimsuits riding sea horses and holding a tan banner that reads "Lake Tahoe 1959" over their heads with their free hands. The women have red bandanas around their necks, and the sea horses have red dorsal fins. A red banner that reads "Queen of the Rodeo" runs across the bottom of the mural.

mods.abstract: The theme of this vibrant mural, painted by members of UTI Crew during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, directly relates to the location in which it is painted: the wall of Headquarters Bar, a bar owned and operated by "Crawl Reno, the organizers of the Reno Zombie Crawl and a ton of other massive parties in downtown Reno" (http://headquartersreno.com/#home_about). On the right side of the mural stands a man with characteristics representative of the various crawls that take place in Reno throughout the year. The red Santa hat he wears with gold polka dots and a gold fur ball gestures towards the Santa Crawl; his green beard gestures towards the Leprechaun Crawl; and the Superman shirt he wears gestures towards the Super Hero Crawl. On the left side of the mural is a zombie with a mask resting on the top of its head, representing both the Zombie and Mardi Gras Crawls. These two figures flank four separate graffiti-style words (one of which appears to be the moniker of one of the UTI Crew members, Spek). In the background of the mural, a city skyline goes up in flames, perhaps caused by the man on the left who holds a lit match in his right hand, a mug of bear in his left. To the left of the mural is a small chain link fence with wood slats upon which "The Crawl" is painted in aqua, turquoise and sky blue horror font against a yellow and orange background with red splatters.

mods.abstract: This 65 x (roughly) 16 foot mural pinated on the wall of Peerless Cleaners by artist Erik Burke combines Reno history and Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is speckled with small symbols that depict prominent Reno figures, organizations, and locations in the business's and city's history. Some of these symbols are connected, like constellations, by a line that carries throughout the composition. The mountain-range landscape can also be interpreted as draped fabric, connecting the mural to the the business located in that building. The mural is painted in shades of red, orange, yellow, blue and white.

mods.abstract: In this mural, artist Anthony Ortega paints a bright owl with super powers roaming the night. The owl is painted in shades of pink, orange, purple, red, beige, and green; it is draped with a blue cloak with geometric shapes. The owl has green light rays beaming from its eyes into the bottom right corner of the mural. The sky is painted in dark blues and black with swirling white clouds. The style of the mural pays homage to Japanese anime, referenced through the animated owl, it's wardrobe, it's "super power," and the anime-style clouds.

mods.abstract: According to artist Joe C. Rock, his mural on the exterior wall of the Renaissance Reno Downtown Hotel "depicts imagery of Reno and the greater-Nevada area. The octagon 'R' is from the second Reno arch that ran from 1963-1987 [and] the background is filled with sage, our state flower. The 'E' is filled with a mountain bluebird, our state bird. The 'N' is inside a silver state of Nevada with a portrait of Jesse Reno, our city's namesake. The 'O' is from the current Reno arch [and sits over] a heart, inside the 'O' is a landscape of Mt. Rose surrounded by a red rose. The piece is finished off with the words 'Home Means Nevada,' our state song" (https://www.instagram.com/p/BUS8FaqDbF4/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13).

mods.abstract: This mural is a three-part piece painted by artist Joe C. Rock. The fence (of three total) here depicts a hand-drawn rudimentary map representing Sparks, Reno, Virginia City and Carson City, Nevada. The sage brush that grows horizontally behind the map peaks through holes in the map and the golden-yellow banner from the Nevada state flag wraps around and through the entire seen. A monochromatic portrait of Kit Carson is painted on the-right side of the fence.

mods.abstract: The back side of Vaka and Sarra's signal-box mural features an off-center close up of a wolf's head and face. The wolf's fur is multicolored: muted shades of purple, yellow, green, blue, and orange. The wolf's eyes are a mint green, its nose is black and purple, and the whiskers on the right side of its face are green, those on the left are purple. Vaka's moniker and the pound sign are painted in white against a black backdrop in the lower-left corner of the box. The wolf likely relates to the signal box's proximity to the University of Nevada, Reno, whose mascot is the wolf.

record.Title: Unknown [Colorful Wolf]
record.Description: The back side of Vaka and Sarra's signal-box mural features an off-center close up of a wolf's head and face. The wolf's fur is multicolored: muted shades of purple, yellow, green, blue, and orange. The wolf's eyes are a mint green, its nose is black and purple, and the whiskers on the right side of its face are green, those on the left are purple. Vaka's moniker and the pound sign are painted in white against a black backdrop in the lower-left corner of the box. The wolf likely relates to the signal box's proximity to the University of Nevada, Reno, whose mascot is the wolf.
record.Sitelocation: Signal box

mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural set against a light blue background depicts a camera with a roll of film unraveling from its film compartment. On the unraveled film can be seen the undeveloped images that the camera has captured. A girl holds her dog; a man hangs out the driver-side window of a van and looks at the camera; a man kneels in front of his bicycle; two children ride their bicycles; a man looks to his left with a city street behind him; a man holds two bags (one in each hand) up in the air and smiles at the camera; a woman stands with her hands in her pockets and smiles at the camera; a young girl looks quizzically at the camera; a young man looks back at the camera from the driver-side window of his car; a man stands with his hands in his pockets in front of a light pole; a man with a thick mustache looks directly at the camera, a skull-like object is to the left of him; four children sit together on some steps; a young girl rides a rocking horse. The film roll ends, leading into an orange burst and then beam of light that perhaps represents the light needed to expose the film. The light beam is surrounded by black, blue, and gray clouds.

mods.abstract: Bryce Chisholm's mural, painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017, features a a vibrant multicolored background. A young woman on the right and a wolf below her on the left have been painted over the background using a stencil (a technique the artist is known for) and black and white paint. Two thin lines with stars surrounding them encircled the woman. A thin white outline of the number 4 (for 4th Street, where the building upon which the mural resides), surrounded by a blue flourish pattern, are painted in the upper-left side of the mural. A aqua-blue houndstooth pattern has been painted, again with a stencil in the upper-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: Michael Lucido's electric-box mural features two sunglass-wearing raccoons on the back. A raccoon holding a video camera in its right hand while flashing a "sign of the horns" gesture (the index finger and the little finger are upright and the thumb is clasped against the two middle fingers) on his left hand sits atop the shoulders of the other raccoon who is performing a kick flip on a sky-blue skateboard with pink wheels, the words "Rad Thief" (a reference to the name of Lucido's clothing company: Rad Thief) appear on the bottom of the board ("Rad Thief" also appears on the video camera). The raccoons are painted against a teal, yellow, and pink background. Three smaller boxes (one blue, one yellow, one pink) sit to the left of the main box. The panel of the box to the right is painted black with the words "Reno Is Rad." All three words have a different appearance: "Reno" is all caps, painted in aqua-blue block letters with magenta shadows; "Is" appears in black caps against a bright yellow banner-like background; "Rad" is painted in white cursive letters, with a white underline. White eight-pointed stars speckle the panel. The skateboarding theme of this box possibly relates to its location at City Park Plaza, used in the past as an unofficial skate park. The video camera might be symbolic Lucido's involvement with multi-media production.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. The top of his head is represented as an open book, and there is a quill pen over his right shoulder.

mods.abstract: At 28 x 140 ft., Erik Burke's mural, Camouflage, is the largest painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. The mural abstracts images such as a pioneer woman riding a horse, cacti, and sheep that represent Nevada's historical past as well as its promising future. The top of the mural reads "Look to the Pasture to see the Future," conveying the influence that the natural landscape, farming and ranching has had in this state.

mods.abstract: The mural on the left, painted by HS, combines graffiti with vibrant animation. Silly monkeys and a cockatoo perched on a branch flank the vibrant graffiti text that emerges from green leaves. The mural on the right, painted by members of UTI Crew, depicts imagery associated with heavy metal band Iron Maiden. The mummy, skeletons, graveyard, and ominous skylines can all be found on various album covers and merchandise. Various graffiti-style words (likely the artists' monikers) appear throughout the mural.

record.Title: Unknown [Monkeys, Leaves, and Birds]; Unknown [Iron Maiden Imagery: Mummy, Skeletons, Cemetery and Skyline]

mods.abstract: This mural painted by artist Erik Burke is composed of two main subjects: a Reno landscape at sunset, and an electrocardiograph line running through the entire mural. The beloved mountains of Northern Nevada are depicted below in black as the blue and black clouds begin to take over the setting sun. The spots of white depicted throughout the black mountains depict life in the city. Life in Reno is further symbolized by the large and vibrant electrocardiograph line (or heartbeat line) painted across the landscape in green and white.

mods.abstract: Erik Burkes describes his mural, Rebuilding the Block, as "a texture dense field of western motifs and a deconstructed cinder block. Atop the pattern sits yellow lines demarcating the layout of the streets, a mile in every direction. A pair of eyes represent the creative visionaries atop a city determined to reinvent itself without any luck or success. The nearby peak of Mt. Rose is anchored at the base of the wall, covering the mouth and serving as a reference point for Reno's most regarded resource...Lake Tahoe" (eriktburke.com). A gray cinder block floats in front of a person's forehead that is framed by hair. Piercing blue eyes stare at the viewer as the facial features begin to fade at the bridge of the nose. Blue, green, and red triangles in ones, twos, and threes speckle the mural and comprise Lake Tahoe at the bottom of the mural, with Mt. Rose rising above. Faint yellow lines representing roads/streets cover the mural. Burke's moniker (OU34) is painted in bright yellow on the bottom-left corner. The mural is 16 x 20 ft.

mods.abstract: This gypsy-like woman, painted by artist Anthony Ortega, fashions a combination of deep-red and golden-yellow hair, wrapped in a green and white gypsy headscarf, embellished with a vibrant yellow flower. She is also accented with dangling golden earrings, blue sleeves, and detailed floral designs on her shoulders. She holds a cocktail in her left hand, displaying her connection to Davidson's distillery, the place upon which the mural was painted.

mods.abstract: This wall on the west side of the building occupied by Nevada Fine Arts contains six 16 x 20 ft. panels, each painted by a different artist. From left to right: Artist Joe C. Rock pays homage to the renowned artist, Georgia O'Keefe, through a surrealist-style head (that of O'Keefe, according to Rock) that explodes with ideas. The mountain on her right shoulder, as well as the hanging flower, refer to subjects in O'Keefe's own artworks. Rock adds a twist to the O'Keefe style by incorporating words in different font styles and vibrant colors such as pink, purple, green, and yellow.; Artist Nanook portrays hands emerging from a turquoise background balancing stones. A blue and green ikat patterned snake-like object winds through the mural, separating the turquoise background from the abstract blue sky above; Erik Burke describes his mural, Rebuilding the Block, as "a texture dense field of western motifs and a deconstructed cinder block. Atop the pattern sits yellow lines demarcating the layout of the streets, a mile in every direction. A pair of eyes represent the creative visionaries atop a city determined to reinvent itself without any luck or success. The nearby peak of Mt. Rose is anchored at the base of the wall, covering the mouth and serving as a reference point for Reno's most regarded resource...Lake Tahoe" (eriktburke.com). A gray cinder block floats in front of a person's forehead, framed by hair. Piercing blue eyes stare at the viewer as the facial features begin to fade at the bridge of the nose. Blue, green, and red triangles in ones, twos, and threes speckle the mural and comprise Lake Tahoe at the bottom of the mural, with Mt. Rose rising above. Faint yellow lines representing roads/streets cover the mural; A vibrant yellow, orange, and red coyote sitting in front of a bronze moon rising amid a monochromatic sky and a mountain range comprised of various shapes, patterns and objects is the focal point of this mural painted by Kelly Peyton. Hearts, lighting bolts, fish skeletons and some words disguise themselves in the coyote's fur; A monochromatic mural painted by artist Fitz portrays a long-haired girl opening a window or roller door to reveal the only polychromatic portion of the mural, an outdoor scene of a lake, mountains and flowers. This scene is flanked on the right by industrial imagery, such as gears and conveyor belts; Artist Bryce Chisholm painted a "Super Boy" on his panel using a stencil (a technique Chisholm is known for). Outfitted in a red and black cape and mask with a star emblazoned on his chest, the boy strikes a heroic pose against a colorful background of various geometric shapes and patterns. Flying pigeons speckle the mural, while one is perched in the upper-left corner.

mods.abstract: "DAYDREAM!" appears in all caps in this mural that artist Joe C. Rock painted on a chain link fence with wood slats. Enclosed within the block letters is green grass against a blue skyline. The letters are outlined in white and cast red shadows outlined in peach. Growing out of the grass in the first "D" is a blue flower. A butterfly with blue wings perches on the outside edge of the second "D" and a lady bug crawls across the grass. A red rose rests on the left side of the "R." A worm slithers through the grass, straddling the right side of the "R" and left side of the "E," disappearing and re-emerging out of the right side of the "E." A blue flower with a lady bug on it grows out of the grass in the dot of the exclamation point.

record.Title: Daydream
record.Description: "DAYDREAM!" appears in all caps in this mural that artist Joe C. Rock painted on a chain link fence with wood slats. Enclosed within the block letters is green grass against a blue skyline. The letters are outlined in white and cast red shadows outlined in peach. Growing out of the grass in the first "D" is a blue flower. A butterfly with blue wings perches on the outside edge of the second "D" and a lady bug crawls across the grass. A red rose rests on the left side of the "R." A worm slithers through the grass, straddling the right side of the "R" and left side of the "E," disappearing and re-emerging out of the right side of the "E." A blue flower with a lady bug on it grows out of the grass in the dot of the exclamation point.
record.Sitelocation: North-facing fence in back of house at 221 Moran St., Reno, NV

mods.abstract: Artists Nanook and Erik Burke painted these two adjacent walls on the back and side of Craft Wine and Beer. On the southern wall, Nanook paints a bull with rooster-patterned fur against a white background with a dark aegean-blue border at the bottom. Three large black circles with mustard-yellow outlines and flowers with dark-red centers speckle the mural and one large red circle appears in the center of the mural. A prominent cerulean-blue curvy line with a lighter and thinner line next to it horizontally spans the mural, weaving through and around the circles and bull. In the bottom left corner of the mural, Nanook's moniker and the date have been painted in the same blue as the curvy line against the dark aegean-blue border. On the eastern wall, Artist Erik Burke painted this beer-and-wine themed, 45 x 18 foot mural to coincide with the business upon which it resides. Dark brown beer bottles and green and pink wine bottles, all with various labels, are painted against a cerulean-blue background. The bottles are painted in a repeating pattern wherein either: one bottle faces right-way up while another is turned upside down with a stream of beer or wine flowing between the mouths of the bottles; or, one bottle faces right-way up while the other is turned upside and the bases of bottles rest on each other. The largest bottle and focal point of the mural is a beer bottle with a monochromatic label depicting a hops farmer and that reads "Craft Wine Beer."

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a trout with vibrantly colored, checkered skin. Among the various patterns in its checkered skin are cherries, PacMan ghosts, chains, peacock feathers, roses, polka dots, and botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern). Below the fish is the message "Lahontan Cutthroat Trout Back From Extinction!" A bee (not visible) hovers behind the trout, holding in its legs a sewing needle through which a piece of pink thread attached to the caudal peduncle of the fish is threaded. To the right of the bee (also not visible) are the words "One Love" and the artist's moniker (Mafat) and date.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.abstract: This mural painted by artist Erik Burke embraces the history of Nevada. Similar to his other murals, this work is composed of two main elements: a landscape, and the words "GO WEST." The landscape depicts the variety of mountain ranges in Nevada, suggested by the variety of color (shades of red and blue) in which they are painted. The landscape also portrays a wild mustang, an animal representative of the "wild west" nature of Nevada. On the right side of the mural appears a female figure holding a lantern, as if guiding the horse and throwing into relief the words "GO WEST." The words are painted in a subtle yellow and white that merges them into the landscape. The lines in between the words, which depict birch trees with Basque tree carvings that are found in the state, weave in front of and behind the mustang and run parallel (and in some cases line up directly with) the building behind the mural (the Silver Legacy Hotel & Casino), further connecting the mural to the city.

mods.abstract: The theme of this electric box is directly related to and represents its location in front of the Lear Theater in Reno, NV. Artist Bryce Chisholm painted a rendering of the theater using black and white paint and a stencil, a technique he is known for. The theater's roof line and columns are outlined in a bright-light blue, and bright yellow was used to paint the lights hanging from the ceiling above the entryway. In the upper-left corner of the box, Chisholm created the illusion of sun rays behind the theater using yellow and deep-orange paint, while a tranquil, watercolor-esque blue sky with hints of yellow appears behind the theater in the upper-right corner. Stencils were again used to paint the damask patterns that appear in teal under the sun rays on the left side of the box and the larger purple ones on the right side. White and yellow paint stream down from the upper-left corner of the box, while white, green and blue paint streams down from the upper-left corner. Chisholm's mo

mods.abstract: The theme of the mural on this detached garage, painted by Joe C. Rock, relates to its location behind Marmot Properties, one of the foremost real estate development companies in Reno, particularly active in the Midtown area. The entire structure is painted bright green. On the front of the garage is the head of a person with their hair covering their face, their right hand cups the lower part of their face. Reno's downtown skyline comprises the top of the head with Mount Rose at its apex. A red and gold crown (a common object in Rock's murals) with a halo of barbed wire floats above the head. On the garage door, the words "The Heart of the City"(with a heart above the "i" in "city") are painted over the head in red with a neon-green outline. Pink hearts appear on the portion of the letters that extend past the head, and the portion covering the head is transparent, revealing imagery behind it. The door is framed by branches of sagebrush and the shadows they cast. "The Heart of the City" might symbolize the centrality of the Midtown district in the greater Reno area, both geographically and culturally.

mods.abstract: Five panels of this wall were painted by five different artists during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. The two here were painted by artists Ahren Hertel and Joe C. Rock. Hertel paints this blue jay in the desert perched atop a cow skull with a stalk of wheat clasped in its beak. Smoke billows behind the bird from a fire burning off in the distance. The plumage on the bird's head and part of the wheat stalk extend past the arched boundary of the mural and into the natural wall upon which the mural is painted; Rock depicts a cowboy riding a wild mustang into the sunset, representative of the Reno Rodeo. A halo of barbed wire floats above the cowboy's hat and a locomotive disguises itself in the body of the mustang. The background is painted bright blue with a beige banner swirling across it that reads "Get Buck Get Broke." Objects, such as grape bundles, crowns (a common object in Rock's murals), hearts and cherries speckle the mural's background.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.

record.Title: Nevada; Nevada Row
record.Description: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.

mods.abstract: This signal box was painted by artist Michael Lucido to look like it has been boarded up and turned into a raccoon fort, as the mural's title suggests. On the front side of the box, a wide-eyed raccoon with its mouth wide open peaks out through an opening between the boards, a bare fish skeleton dangles from its left paw, its tail pokes out through a hole in a board. The words "Raccoons Only" appear in red below the raccoon, and Lucido's last name, website (www.thatlucidokid.com) and the date are painted in black at the very bottom of the box.

mods.abstract: The eastern wall of the Circus Circus Reno contains seven 20 x 14 ft. panels, each painted by a different artist during the 2017 24-Hour Mural Marathon competition. From left to right: Anthony Ortega won the competition with a psychedelic mural composition that combines ancient Mesoamerican art with futuristic elements. This mural is painted with vibrant shades of blue, red, green, orange, yellow, pink, and purple, portraying a vivid ancient Mesoamerican god-like figure that emerges from the stellar depths of the galaxy behind it and begins it descent into the green forest that surrounds the outer edges of the mural; Kendel Leslie painted a colorful mural with a blue humpback whale as the primary subject. The whale is painted in several shades of blue and purple. The background is composed of different shapes and formed in light pink, magenta, lime green, pastel yellow and purple among a black background with white stars, alluding to a galaxy-like ocean; Artist Raphael Blanco's mural depicts a child taking a photograph using a vintage camera. Although the child is painted predominantly with black, Blanco also uses the colors of the background (blue and purple) for the child's skin color and to create highlights in his/her hair. The background is composed of stripes in an array of shades of blue and purple. There are also translucent white splashes "splattered" around the child; Seth McCorkle depicted a boy with a pointed hat looking ahead. Behind, there is a landscape scene composed of brown hills and bright blue skies; Hannah Sproul painted a turquoise skeleton with a burning cigarette clenched in its teeth against a periwinkle blue background. Flowers in an array of sizes and colors ( blue, yellow, pink, and white) emerge from the bottom of the mural, surrounding the skeleton. Large strips of paint (light pink, yellow, magenta, sky blue, and pastel orange) drip down from the top of the mural; Stephane Cellier depicted a man with a a sword. He stands among mist with a grey background behind; Marv Riley depicted the head of a ferocious tiger with an ornate frame surrounding it over a maroon background.

mods.abstract: The mural on the two adjacent back walls of Mountain Music Parlor was painted by a group of youth who are part of the Children's Cabinet's "Spray Positive" program. This program was instigated by the Reno Police Department, in collaboration with the Children's Cabinet, as a way to beautify blighted properties in Midtown and Downtown Reno. A dream catcher with music notes in the web leads to the head of a Native-American figure wearing an elaborate headdress. An American flag emerges from the left side of the headdress and straddles both walls. A portrait of a man in a cowboy hat (most likely bluegrass musician Bill Monroe) painted in front of the flag graces the adjacent wall, and the mural concludes with a rendering of a chick playing a cello with the name "Bill Monroe" painted above it.

mods.abstract: Artists Troy Lovegates, Collin van der Sluijis and Joe C. Rock painted adjacent walls at the top of this building during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. The collaborative mural painted by Troy Lovegates and Collin van der Sluijis on the left portrays several symbols of Nevada's history, landscape, wildlife and fauna. A mountain bluebird is flanked on the left by the upper body of a monochromatic Native American man and on the right by Canadian Geese flying in front of the lower body of a cowboy-boot-wearing individual. The mural is further embellished with feathers, various flowers, pyramids, and red and yellow polka dots. As artist Joe C. Rock explains, his mural on the right "featur[es] the arm of my mother stretched across 2nd St... representing her strength and commitment to diversity with her 65 year old freshly tattooed arm piece...I was raised by my mother my entire childhood in a single parent home, she did everything she could do to get me to make the right choices in life and did whatever she needed to do to provide the best life for my cousins, sister and myself, sacrificing her own needs for ours" (https://www.instagram.com/p/Bb-uzY6Dwyr/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13) & (<https://www.instagram.com/p/BeL5LzdDuCN/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13>).

A mountain bluebird is flanked on the left by the upper body of a monochromatic Native American man and on the right by Canadian Geese flying in front of the lower body of a cowboy-boot-wearing individual. The mural is further embellished with feathers, various flowers, pyramids, and red and yellow polka dots. As artist Joe C. Rock explains, his mural on the right "featur[es] the arm of my mother stretched across 2nd St... representing her strength and commitment to diversity with her 65 year old freshly tattooed arm piece...I was raised by my mother my entire childhood in a single parent home, she did everything she could do to get me to make the right choices in life and did whatever she needed to do to provide the best life for my cousins, sister and myself, sacrificing her own needs for ours" (https://www.instagram.com/p/Bb-uzY6Dwyr/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13) & (<https://www.instagram.com/p/BeL5LzdDuCN/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13>).

mods.abstract: At 28 x 140 ft., Erik Burke's mural, Camouflage, is the largest painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. The mural abstracts images such as a pioneer woman on riding a horse, cacti, and sheep that represent Nevada's historical past as well as its promising future. The top of the mural reads "Look to the Pasture to see the Future," conveying the influence that the natural landscape, farming and ranching has had in this state.

mods.abstract: A red classic car with a white roof wraps around the front and right side of Vaka's signal-box mural. Yellow and light-purple hand prints adorn the grill of the car and yellow, light-purple and light-blue hand prints appear below the bumper. A black mountainous skyline with a pink "Reno" painted over it in pink is depicted in the car's license plate. Vaka's moniker is painted on the top of the right side in purple and white. The content and theme of the mural (the classic car and Monroe eating a burger) relates to the location in which the signal box resides: in front of Juicy's Giant Hamburgers, a popular restaurant in Reno with the feel of an old-fashioned burger joint.

mods.abstract: Deep-orange lilies, painted by Random Act, flank the Buddha-like figure with three eyes, the middle of which has green and magenta rays beaming from it towards the sky that was painted by Garrison Buxton. A rainbow of colors emerge from the figure's mouth, eventually casting an orange and lavender background upon which the phrase "Thoughts Are Things" is painted in white. The yin-and-yang symbol hangs on a green necklace around the figure's neck, below which the phrase "Know Thy Self" appears on a banner across the figure's torso. To the right of the figure, the phrase "Be Kind" is painted in white against a periwinkle background. Buxton's moniker is painted in metallic gold on the bottom-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: In this mural painted by artists Yale Wolf and Tipton Power during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, a dark night sky with yellow stars swirls behind a teal blue classic Cadillac with a white roof that drives, or rather, flies, over a tumultuous sea. The front license plate of the Cadillac reads "LOWFLY" and the rear plate reads "B4L8R" (suggesting there might actually be two separate cars). The mural inside the garage below was painted by a different artist at a different time.

mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural set against a light blue background depicts a camera with a roll of film unraveling from its film compartment. On the unraveled film can be seen the undeveloped images that the camera has captured. A girl holds her dog; a man hangs out the driver-side window of a van and looks at the camera; a man kneels in front of his bicycle; two children ride their bicycles; a man looks to his left with a city street behind him; a man holds two bags (one in each hand) up in the air and smiles at the camera; a woman stands with her hands in her pockets and smiles at the camera; a young girl looks quizzically at the camera; a young man looks back at the camera from the driver-side window of his car; a man stands with his hands in his pockets in front of a light pole; a man with a thick mustache looks directly at the camera, a skull-like object is to the left of him; four children sit together on some steps; a young girl rides a rocking horse. The film roll ends, leading into an orange burst and then beam of light that perhaps represents the light needed to expose the film. The light beam is surrounded by black, blue, and gray clouds.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts inebriated individuals floating on the surface of a red sea, flanked by the Roman god of the sea, Neptune, and the Roman god of agriculture, wine and fertility, Bacchus. Lighting bolts strike the red water from an ominous cloudy sky above. On the left of this scene, the words "Craft Wine -n-Beer" are painted vertically, and in the lower-right corner of the mural, against the red-sea background, the quote "Bacchus Hath Drowned more Men than Neptune. -Dr. Thomas Fuller" is etched on a placard flanked by roses. The entire mural is monochromatic, with the exception of the red sea.

mods.abstract: The theme of this vibrant mural, painted by members of UTI Crew during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, directly relates to the location in which it is painted: the wall of Headquarters Bar, a bar owned and operated by "Crawl Reno, the organizers of the Reno Zombie Crawl and a ton of other massive parties in downtown Reno" (http://headquartersreno.com/#home_about). On the right side of the mural stands a man with characteristics representative of the various crawls that take place in Reno throughout the year. The red Santa hat he wears with gold polka dots and a gold fur ball gestures towards the Santa Crawl; his green beard gestures towards the Leprechaun Crawl; and the Superman shirt he wears gestures towards the Super Hero Crawl. On the left side of the mural is a zombie with a mask resting on the top of its head, representing both the Zombie and Mardi Gras Crawls. These two figures flank four separate graffiti-style words (one of which appears to be the moniker of one of the UTI Crew members, Spek). In the background of the mural, a city skyline goes up in flames, perhaps caused by the man on the left who holds a lit match in his right hand, a mug of bear in his left. To the left of the mural is a small chain link fence with wood slats upon which "The Crawl" is painted in aqua, turquoise and sky blue horror font against a yellow and orange background with red splatters.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

record.Title: In the Midst of Midtown

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a trout with vibrantly colored, checkered skin. Among the various patterns in its checkered skin are cherries, PacMan ghosts, chains, peacock feathers, roses, polka dots, and botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern). Below the fish is the message "Lahontan Cutthroat Trout Back From Extinction!" A bee hovers behind the trout, holding in its legs a sewing needle through which a piece of pink thread attached to the caudal peduncle of the fish is threaded. To the right of the bee are the words "One Love" and the artist's moniker (Mafat) and date.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a large brown octopus mixed with peacock feathers and a human-like figure. The octopus is the focus of the mural. The body of the octopus is painted in a palette of browns, while its suckers are painted in a palette of blue. The peacock feathers almost resemble the suckers as they intertwine into the octopus's tentacles. The tentacles wrap around and burst through a portrait of a blue human-like figure wearing headphones that emerges from the mud-cracked ground, perhaps representing Burning Man since the business upon which the mural is painted, The Melting Pot World Emporium, is one of the leading retailers of Playa gear in the area. The figure stares out into the distance. A tentacle bursts through the middle portrait, which depicts the Burning Man logo centered in the Burning-Man-Playa landscape with planets hanging in the night sky above. The last portrait is a circus-style wall sign for the The Melting Pot. A curtain opens up to a stage with silhouettes of people dancing in front of an earth with sun rays around it. The background of the entire mural is painted a bright red, contrasting the aquatic and desert ambiance of the subject matter.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com).A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Here the top of his head is represented as an open book, and there is a quill pen over his right shoulder.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts an abstracted city landscape. The mural is divided into three sections: the sky, the mountain ranges, and the cityscape. The sky is covered by yellow and green clouds. They merge into the dark red mountains. Underneath the mountains is a bright red path that leads to the blue and green geometric shapes that resemble a city.

mods.abstract: Two smiling hispanic woman are depicted in this monochromatic mural installed by Dr. Chip Thomas during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. On the left, an older woman rests her head on the shoulder of a younger woman with her right hand raised to and resting on the right side of her face. On the older woman's cheek are the words "We Are Powerful" and on the left side of the younger woman's face, on her eyelid and cheek, are the words "No Somos Cien Somos Milliones Cuentanos Bien (We are not one. We Are not hundreds. We are millions. Count us well." The mural gestures towards the presence and vital role of the hispanic community in the U.S.

mods.abstract: This wall on the west side of the building occupied by Nevada Fine Arts contains six 16 x 20 ft. panels, each painted by a different artist. From left to right: Artist Joe C. Rock pays homage to the renowned artist, Georgia O'Keefe, through a surrealist-style head (that of O'Keefe, according to Rock) that explodes with ideas. The mountain on her right shoulder, as well as the hanging flower, refer to subjects in O'Keefe's own artworks. mods.abstract: Artist Vaka paints a close up of a woman's face with a dotting technique and using mainly shades of blue and purple, with highlights and shadows of green, yellow, orange and red. She has seductive golden eyes, and round blue pearl-like objects run across her cheeks from her temples to her nostrils. Red, gold and green hair frames the right side of her face while purple feathers flank the left side.

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. Please refer to the organization that has made the item available for more information. You are free to use this item in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. http://rightsstatements.org/vocab/UND/1.0/
mods.abstract: This wall on the west side of the building occupied by Nevada Fine Arts contains six 16 x 20 ft. panels, each painted by a different artist. From left to right: Artist Joe C. Rock pays homage to the renowned artist, Georgia O'Keefe, through a surrealist-style head (that of O'Keefe, according to Rock) that explodes with ideas. The mountain on her right shoulder, as well as the hanging flower, refer to subjects in O'Keefe's own artworks. Rock adds a twist to the O'Keefe style by incorporating words in different font styles and vibrant colors such as pink, purple, green, and yellow.; Artist Nanook portrays hands emerging from a turquoise background balancing stones. A blue and green ikat patterned snake-like object winds through the mural, separating the turquoise background from the abstract blue sky above; Erik Burke describes his mural, Rebuilding the Block, as "a texture dense field of western motifs and a deconstructed cinder block. Atop the pattern sits yellow lines demarcating the layout of the streets, a mile in every direction. A pair of eyes represent the creative visionaries atop a city determined to reinvent itself without any luck or success. The nearby peak of Mt. Rose is anchored at the base of the wall, covering the mouth and serving as a reference point for Reno's most regarded resource...Lake Tahoe" (eriktburke.com). A gray cinder block floats in front of a person's forehead, framed by hair. Piercing blue eyes stare at the viewer as the facial features begin to fade at the bridge of the nose. Blue, green, and red triangles in ones, twos, and threes speckle the mural and comprise Lake Tahoe at the bottom of the mural, with Mt. Rose rising above. Faint yellow lines representing roads/streets cover the mural; A vibrant yellow, orange, and red coyote sitting in front of a bronze moon rising amid a monochromatic sky and a mountain range comprised of various shapes, patterns and objects is the focal point of this mural painted by Kelly Peyton. Hearts, lighting bolts, fish skeletons and some words disguise themselves in the coyote's fur; A monochromatic mural painted by artist Fitz portrays a long-haired girl opening a window or roller door to reveal the only polychromatic portion of the mural, an outdoor scene of a lake, mountains and flowers. This scene is flanked on the right by industrial imagery, such as gears and conveyor belts; Artist Bryce Chisholm painted a "Super Boy" on his panel using a stencil (a technique Chisholm is known for). Outfitted in a red and black cape and mask with a star emblazoned on his chest, the boy strikes a heroic pose against a colorful background of various geometric shapes and patterns. Flying pigeons speckle the mural, while one is perched in the upper-left corner.

mods.abstract: Artist Stephane Cellier used the natural angles of the wall upon which he painted this monochromatic mural during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 to create an optical illusion. An "x" accompanied by "please stand here to view the mural" is painted on the the ground, marking the "sweet spot" from where the intended depiction of the mural can be correctly and fully observed: a man receiving a kiss on the cheek from a woman with words above that read "Two Smiles Getting Closer End Up Making...A Kiss." Viewed head-on, the mural is a distorted mess.

mods.abstract: This mural is a three-part piece painted by artist Joe C. Rock. The fence here (of three total) contains a monochromatic portrait of Jesse Lee Reno. Sage brush grows horizontally from his face. To the left of Reno, Nevada's nickname/slogan "Battle Born" is painted in black along the length of the fence, against a rich blue background. A mountain bluebird perches on the sagebrush in front of the "B" in "Born." The golden-yellow banner from the Nevada state flag wraps around flows through the entire scene.

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. You are free to use this item in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. http://rightsstatements.org/vocab/UND/1.0/
mods.abstract: Christina Angelina's mural, painted during the Inaugural Reno Sculpture Fest in 2015, features a young female figure wearing a dark grey hood over her long wavy black hair. She looks directly at the viewer, and holds a silver frame against her body. The mural was painted using a palette of blues, grays, silver and black and using a technique wherein the paint streams down from the very top of the mural to create movement in the composition. Due to the mural's considerably large scale (approximately 35 x 80 ft.), spanning the entire height of a seven-story parking garage, the young woman seems to look down upon or watch over the downtown-Reno area. After being told by a homeless man in Reno that the young woman is his angel, Angelina said: "That people sleep under this artwork to feel safer downtown [m]akes me like this piece even more" (https://www.instagram.com/p/BUx2SQUlhIj/?hl=en&taken-by=starfightera). The mural on the right was painted by artist Ricky Lee Gordon during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. Gordon painted a female figure with the word "nature" hovering over her. Gordon uses dark colors to obscure the woman's face. The woman represents the Native American community in northern Nevada and the importance of conserving nature. A messages in the lower-right corner of the mural reads "Nature Conspires with Spirit to Emancipate Us."

record.Title: Unknown [Angel of Reno]; Unknown [Nature]

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains, his mural painted by Joe C. Rock during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 "featur[es] the arm of my mother stretched across 2nd St... representing her strength and commitment to diversity with her 65 year old freshly tattooed arm piece...I was raised by my mother my entire childhood in a single parent home, she did everything she could do to get me to make the right choices in life and did whatever she needed to do to provide the best life for my cousins, sister and myself, sacrificing her own needs for ours" (https://www.instagram.com/p/Bb-uzY6Dwyr/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13) & (https://www.instagram.com/p/BeL5LzdDuCN/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13).

mods.abstract: This mural, painted as a tribute to September 11, 2001, contains classic patriotic-American imagery. On the left side of the mural, a bald eagle appears behind the word "September" that is painted in blue block letters with "9/11,""2001," and "2011" painted within them. To the right of this are the silhouettes of what appear to be construction workers raising the American flag. Next, a rendering of the New York City skyline appears. The sun glows bright yellow behind both the flag-raising construction workers and the skyline. Last, the Statue of Liberty's head and her torch are depicted in profile.

mods.abstract: Two smiling hispanic woman are depicted in this monochromatic mural installed by Dr. Chip Thomas during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. On the left, an older woman rests her head on the shoulder of a younger woman with her right hand raised to and resting on the right side of her face. On the older woman's cheek are the words "We Are Powerful" and on the left side of the younger woman's face, on her eyelid and cheek, are the words "No Somos Cien Somos Milliones Cuentanos Bien (We are not one. We Are not hundreds. We are millions. Count us well." The mural gestures towards the presence and vital role of the hispanic community in the U.S.

mods.abstract: This 65 x (roughly) 16 foot mural pinated on the wall of Peerless Cleaners by artist Erik Burke combines Reno history and Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is speckled with small symbols that depict prominent Reno figures, organizations, and locations in the business's and city's history. Some of these symbols are connected, like constellations, by a line that carries throughout the composition. The mountain-range landscape can also be interpreted as draped fabric, connecting the mural to the the business located in that building. The mural is painted in shades of red, orange, yellow, blue and white.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood. The US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40.

subject.geographic: North-facing garage doors on apartment building behind house at 223 Moran St., Reno, NV

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. mods.abstract: Each of these three garage doors, painted by artist Joe C. Rock, contains one of the three components that make up the proverbial principle: speak no evil, hear no evil, see no evil. The principle is phrased on the doors as "Speak, Hear, & See." On the first door, a man covers his mouth with his right hand, a letter of the word "LOVE" is tattooed on each finger. A lady bug rests on the base of his thumb. A red banner outlined in gold with the word "Speak" painted in white covers his eyes. On the second door, a man covers both his hears with his hands. A black widow crawls downward in front of his left hand. The word "Hear" appears in white on the red banner that wraps around his head, covering both of his ears. On the third garage, a man covers his eyes with his left hand. A worm on a hook attached to a line that carries through the entire mural is laced through his fingers, each of which have a letter of the word "Hate" tattooed on them. The words "& See" are painted in white on the red banner that covers the man's mouth. A bee with a crown (a common object in Rock's murals) floating above its head flies in the upper-left corner of the third door.

mods.abstract: This signal box was painted by artist Michael Lucido to look like it has been boarded up and turned into a raccoon fort, as the mural's title suggests. On the right side of the box, a wide-eyed raccoon with its mouth wide open stands outside the fort with a Campbell's Tomato Soup can in its left paw and a paint brush in its right paw. Red tomato soup is on the tip of the brush, as well as on the raccoon's tongue and around its mouth. The words "Rad City" are painted in red on a board above the raccoon's head. The back side of the box depicts a ladder leading into the fort and the artist's last name (Lucido) painted in bright green appears all over the boards.

mods.abstract: The back side of Ashley Follmer's signal-box mural depicts a figure wearing a black suit, white-collared shirt and magenta neck tie. The figure stands with hands in pockets and the section of the figure where the neck and head should be erupts into a huge cloud that transitions from dark blue on the left, to light blue, to white, to pink, to magenta on the right. This figure is painted against a background that transitions from bright yellow at the top to deep orange at the bottom. The subject of this mural might relate to its location on the University of Nevada, Reno campus: perhaps the figure's head is exploding from the knowledge it has acquired (as in, "mind blown!").

mods.abstract: The focal point of artist Seth McCorkle's signal-box mural is the mountain chickadee, common in the mountains of Nevada. On the back side of the box, a single dickadee is perched on a branch of a plant or tree, with a little green foliage on it. A cerulean-blue body of water appears in the background, with a light blue sky with fluffy-white clouds above. McCorkle's moniker and the date are painted in light blue on the bottom-left corner of the box.

mods.abstract: The face depicted in this mural by artist Bryce Chisholm was painted using a stencil (a technique the artist is known for) and purple, magenta, salmon, green, aqua-blue and dark-blue paint. Mint-green rays of light with birds flying through and beyond them shine down behind the face. Various-sized blue stars outlined in gold speckle the mural, starting at the left cheek of the face and spanning the remainder of mural to the right. To the right of the face, a black and white cheetah sits atop a light-purple hill with delicate plants growing from it. Three large circles comprised of small individual concentric white, blue, and gold brush strokes appear behind and to the left of the face, in the middle of the wall; to the right of the face, between the hair and light rays, towards the bottom of the wall; and to the right of cheetah, towards the middle of the wall. Chisholm's moniker (ABC Art Attack) and the date are painted in white with blue outline at the top of the right side of the mural.

mods.abstract: According to artist Erik Burke who painted this 18 x 50 foot mural, "The Hudson Project is a block of mixed-use urban infill development between Center and Lake Street on State Street. The mural graces the east side of the development and is a visualization of all the people and business that inhabited this block dating back to 1890" (http://eriktburke.com/Hudson-Project). The upper portion of the left side of the mural is composed of various vibrant shades of green while the bottom portion depicting a landscape is composed of a vibrant blue, brown/tan, yellow, and more green. The right side of the mural is a wheat pasted silhouette profile of a man conducting a land survey against a large white circle (perhaps representing the moon). This technique creates a life-like, almost 3D depiction of the man, the colors of which tie in with the left portion of the mural.

mods.abstract: This 65 x (roughly) 16 foot mural pinated on the wall of Peerless Cleaners by artist Erik Burke combines Reno history and Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is speckled with small symbols that depict prominent Reno figures, organizations, and locations in the business's and city's history. Some of these symbols are connected, like constellations, by a line that carries throughout the composition. The mountain-range landscape can also be interpreted as draped fabric, connecting the mural to the the business located in that building. The mural is painted in shades of red, orange, yellow, blue and white.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock pays homage to the renowned artist, Georgia O'Keefe, through a surrealist-style head (that of O'Keefe, according to Rock) that explodes with ideas. The mountain on her left shoulder, as well as the hanging flower, refer subjects in O'Keefe's own artworks. Rock adds a twist to the O'Keefe style by incorporating words in different font styles and vibrant colors such as pink, purple, green, and yellow.

mods.abstract: Christina Angelina's mural, painted during the Inaugural Reno Sculpture Fest in 2015, features a young female figure wearing a dark grey hood over her long wavy black hair. She looks directly at the viewer, and holds a silver frame against her body. The mural was painted using a palette of blues, grays, silver and black and using a technique wherein the paint streams down from the very top of the mural to create movement in the composition. Due to the mural's considerably large scale (approximately 35 x 80 ft.), spanning the entire height of a seven-story parking garage, the young woman seems to look down upon or watch over the downtown-Reno area. After being told by a homeless man in Reno that the young woman is his angel, Angelina said: "That people sleep under this artwork to feel safer downtown [m]akes me like this piece even more" (https://www.instagram.com/p/BUx2SQUlhIj/?hl=en&taken-by=starfightera).

mods.abstract: Artist Stephane Cellier used the natural angles of the wall upon which he painted this monochromatic mural during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 to create an optical illusion. An "x" accompanied by "please stand here to view the mural" is painted on the the ground, marking the "sweet spot" from where the intended depiction of the mural can be correctly and fully observed: a man receiving a kiss on the cheek from a woman with words above that read "Two Smiles Getting Closer End Up Making...A Kiss." Viewed head-on, the mural is a distorted mess.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.abstract: Kendel Leslie's signal-box mural is dedicated to the preservation of Nevada's wilderness and wildlife. On the front side of the box, a coyote and pronghorn antelope are painted in the foreground. A red cactus pear grows in front of the coyote, and dessert or mountain grass grows in front of the antelope. Behind the the animals are the rolling brown hills of the Nevada dessert, behind which are the snow-capped Sierras. The sky is speckled with puffy white clouds. Leslie's moniker is painted in tiny-black letters in the bottom left corner of the box.

mods.abstract: Anthony Ortega won the 2017 24-Hour Mural Marathon competition with a psychedelic mural composition that combines ancient Mesoamerican art with futuristic elements. This mural is painted with vibrant shades of blue, red, green, orange, yellow, pink, and purple, portraying a vivid ancient Mesoamerican god-like figure that emerges from the stellar depths of the galaxy behind it and begins its descent into the green forest that surrounds the outer edges of the mural.

mods.abstract: During the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, artist Ricky Lee Gordon painted a female figure with the word "NATURE" hovering over her. Gordon uses dark colors to obscure the woman's face. The woman represents the Native American community in northern Nevada and the importance of conserving nature. A message in the lower-right corner of the mural reads "Nature Conspires with Spirit to Emancipate Us."

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe, explaining the basket behind the top of her head.

mods.abstract: This mural painted by artist Joshua Coffy during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 features a black bear with ryukin fish swimming around it. The bottom third of the mural's background is an aegean-blue color, perhaps representative of water, while the rest of the background is tan with chiffon circles (or bubbles). A grid of eleven colors has been painted in the top middle of the mural.

mods.abstract: The upper portion of the profile of a wolf howling against a blue, green and white background appears on the left side of Vaka and Sarra's signal-box mural. The wolf's fur is multicolored: shades of purple, yellow, green, blue, and orange. The colors on this side of the box are a bit more vibrant than those on the other sides. Sarra's moniker is painted in tan against a black back drop in the upper-left corner of the box. The wolf likely relates to the signal box's proximity to the University of Nevada, Reno, whose mascot is the wolf.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.

record.Title: Nevada; Nevada Row
record.Description: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.

mods.abstract: This music-themed mural behind Recycled Records was painted by a group of youth who are part of the Children's Cabinet's "Spray Positive" program. This program was instigated by the Reno Police Department, in collaboration with the Children's Cabinet, as a way to beautify blighted properties in Midtown and Downtown Reno. On the left is a large magenta piano. In the middle, a man wearing a teal fedora, pink shirt, and blue sport coat plays the trumpet. On the right is the abstract profile of a person listening to music on Beats-by-Dre headphones. A curvy music staff flows through the background of the entire composition with green, red, pink, blue and yellow music notes and treble clefs floating along and around it, while a curvy thread of black and white piano keys flows through the foreground of the composition, eventually morphing into the wire that plugs into the headphones.

mods.abstract: A close up of a wolf's head and face wraps around the back and right side of Vaka and Sarra's mural. The wolf's fur is multicolored: muted shades of purple, yellow, green, blue, and orange. The wolf's eyes are a mint green, its nose is black and purple, and the whiskers on the right side of its face are green, those on the left are purple. Two brown hand prints appear towards the bottom of the left side of the box. Vaka's moniker and the pound sign are painted in white against a black backdrop in the lower-left corner of the back side of the box. The wolf likely relates to the signal box's proximity to the University of Nevada, Reno, whose mascot is the wolf.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock combines United States history with the history of Nevada in this mural that was commissioned to celebrate the Historic Lincoln Highway. Abraham Lincoln appears on the left side of the mural, leading to the Nevada flag and then U.S. flag, over which the words "LINCOLN HIGHWAY" are painted in different font styles and are flanked by the Nevada flag and the Interstate 40 highway sign. All subjects combined, this mural conveys the relevance of this president and his namesake highway.

mods.abstract: Artist Vaka paints a close up of a woman's face with a dotting technique and using mainly shades of blue and purple, with highlights and shadows of green, yellow, orange and red. She has seductive golden eyes, and round blue pearl-like objects run across her cheeks from her temples to her nostrils. Red, gold and green hair frames the right side of her face while purple feathers flank the left side. Above the woman, a light-purple cat with bright-blue eyes peers over the window that separates them.

Above the woman, a light-purple cat with bright-blue eyes peers over the window that separates them.

mods.abstract: Bryce Chisholm's mural, painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017, features a a vibrant multicolored background. A young woman on the right and a wolf below her on the left have been painted over the background using a stencil (a technique the artist is known for) and black and white paint. Two thin lines with stars surrounding them encircle the woman. A thin white outline of the number 4 (for 4th Street, where the building upon which the mural resides), surrounded by a blue flourish pattern, are painted in the upper-left side of the mural. An aqua-blue houndstooth pattern has been painted, again with a stencil, in the upper-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock depicts a cowboy riding a wild mustang into the sunset, representative of the Reno Rodeo, in this mural painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. A halo of barbed wire floats above the cowboy's hat and a locomotive disguises itself in the body of the mustang. The background is painted bright blue with a beige banner swirling across it that reads "Get Buck Get Broke." Objects, such as grape bundles, crowns (a common object in Rock's murals), hearts and cherries speckle the mural's background.

mods.abstract: This mural painted by artist Joe C. Rock represents the city of Reno, as well as the Statewide Lighting & Accents company (where the mural resides). The center of the mural highlights a large brightly-lit light bulb with a crown (a common object in Rock's paintings) sitting at the top. Behind the light bulb, the city's well-known "Reno" sign hides, acknowledging the brightness of the rising city. The word "BRIGHT" is also woven within the mural behind leaves and orange circles. Underneath the light bulb, the ground from which the bulb rises is visible; the word "IDEAS" is written through a depiction of stones.

mods.abstract: An aqua-blue alien head with bulbous black eyes painted against a black background is the subject of this mural painted by artist Jamie Darragh during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo that took place in October of 2017. The alien's head is adorned with a metallic-gold head piece with nine graduated white circles centered above. Three different metallic-gold medallions float behind the alien head and seven different moon phases are depicted above the alien's head. Metallic gold appears at the very top of the mural. Darragh's Instagram handle, @j.darragh.art, is painted in metallic gold on the bottom-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

record.Title: In the Midst of Midtown
record.Description: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader.

record.Title: Nevada; Nevada Row
record.Description: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader.

mods.abstract: This mural is a three-part piece painted by artist Joe C. Rock. The fence here (of three total) depicts a hand-drawn rudimentary map representing Sparks, Reno, Virginia City and Carson City, Nevada. The sage brush that grows horizontally behind the map peaks through holes in the map and the golden-yellow banner from the Nevada state flag wraps around and through the entire seen. A monochromatic portrait of Kit Carson is painted on the-right side of the fence.
