mods.abstract: This 65 x (roughly) 16 foot mural pinated on the wall of Peerless Cleaners by artist Erik Burke combines Reno history and Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is speckled with small symbols that depict prominent Reno figures, organizations, and locations in the business's and city's history. Some of these symbols are connected, like constellations, by a line that carries throughout the composition. The mountain-range landscape can also be interpreted as draped fabric, connecting the mural to the the business located in that building. The mural is painted in shades of red, orange, yellow, blue and white.

mods.abstract: In this mural by artist Raphael Blanco, painted during the 24-Hour Mural Marathon in 2017, Blanco depicts a child taking a photograph using a vintage camera. Although the child is painted predominantly with black, Blanco also uses the colors of the background (blue and purple) for the child's skin color and to create highlights in his/her hair. The background is composed of stripes in an array of shades of blue and purple. There are also translucent white splashes "splattered" around the child.

mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural set against a light blue background depicts a camera with a roll of film unraveling from its film compartment. On the unraveled film can be seen the undeveloped images that the camera has captured. A girl holds her dog; a man hangs out the driver-side window of a van and looks at the camera; a man kneels in front of his bicycle; two children ride their bicycles; a man looks to his left with a city street behind him; a man holds two bags (one in each hand) up in the air and smiles at the camera; a woman stands with her hands in her pockets and smiles at the camera; a young girl looks quizzically at the camera; a young man looks back at the camera from the driver-side window of his car; a man stands with his hands in his pockets in front of a light pole; a man with a thick mustache looks directly at the camera, a skull-like object is to the left of him; four children sit together on some steps; a young girl rides a rocking horse. The film roll ends, leading into an orange burst and then beam of light that perhaps represents the light needed to expose the film. The light beam is surrounded by black, blue, and gray clouds.

mods.abstract: This collaborative mural painted by Troy Lovegates and Collin van der Sluijis during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017 portrays several symbols of Nevada's history, landscape, wildlife and fauna. A mountain bluebird is flanked on the left by the upper body of a monochromatic Native American man and on the right by Canadian Geese flying in front of the lower body of a cowboy-boot-wearing individual. The mural is further embellished with feathers, various flowers, pyramids, and red and yellow polka dots.

mods.abstract: This 65 x (roughly) 16 foot mural pinated on the wall of Peerless Cleaners by artist Erik Burke combines Reno history and Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is speckled with small symbols that depict prominent Reno figures, organizations, and locations in the business's and city's history. Some of these symbols are connected, like constellations, by a line that carries throughout the composition. The mountain-range landscape can also be interpreted as draped fabric, connecting the mural to the the business located in that building. The mural is painted in shades of red, orange, yellow, blue and white.

subject.geographic: Dumpster enclosure behind Nevada Museum of Art at 160 W. Liberty St., Reno, NV

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. mods.abstract: This mural was painted by artist Erik Burke on a cinderblock trash-can enclosure located behind the Nevada Museum of Art (NMA) to coincide with the Tilted Basin Exhibition that ran at the NMA from August through October of 2016. The entire enclose was painted in a vibrant lime green and the male and female figures represented horizontally on the left side, presumably a father and daughter dancing, are painted on top of the lime-green background using darker shades of green and black paint. Dark-green paint was used to create a cat-like design on the portion of the girl's dress that covers her arms, shoulders and upper back, and to create a simple floral pattern on the remaining (lower) portion of the dress. A bit a of white paint was used to create the metal appearance of the man's wedding band and to paint Burke's moniker (OU37) in the upper-left corner. According to the NMA website, the Tilted Basin Exhibition "bridges the divide between Northern and Southern Nevada communities and provides a wide-ranging overview and understanding of the most accomplished work being created by more than thirty artists living and working in Nevada today." This mural was replaced during the 2017 Reno Mural Expo by one painted by artist Dr. Chip Thompson (that mural can be found in this archive under "Unknown [We Are Powerful]).

mods.abstract: This signal-box mural by Devin Hosselkus is Reno themed. Reno's slogan,"Reno: the Biggest Little City in the World," wraps around the box, as do renderings of the various versions of the Reno arches (the original version with slogan: installed in 1929; the second version: installed in 1963; and the current version: installed in 1987). Hosselkus used a simple color palette consisting of navy blue, teal, red, tan and brown, grey, white, and black.

subject.geographic: Southern wall of warehouse at 2233 Dickerson Rd., Reno, NV

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. Please refer to the organization that has made the item available for more information. mods.abstract: Painted on a warehouse on Dickerson Road, a location known to draw in local street artists, this mural conveys the vibrancy of the art culture there. Composed by several different artists, this mural combines portraiture, animations and vibrant colors that become a collage of a mural. The mural depicts two portraits of women, a pink animated cat-like figure, a four-eyed monster wearing a party hat, a large peanut, a floating brick wall with a graffiti artist painting on it, and a Day of the Dead skull. The mural overall is painted in shades of blue, pink, green, yellow, red, green, grey, and beige.

mods.abstract: Artist Ahren Hertel painted this blue jay in the desert perched atop a cow skull with a stalk of wheat clasped in its beak during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. Smoke billows behind the bird from a fire burning off in the distance. The plumage on the bird's head and part of the wheat stalk extend past the arched boundary of the mural and into the natural wall upon which the mural is painted.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley, as symbolized by the brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of his head.

record.Title: Nevada; Nevada Row
record.Description: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley, as symbolized by the brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of his head.

mods.abstract: This collaborative mural by artists Erik Burke and Labrona (from Montreal) resided (has since been painted over) at the Holland Project, "an all-ages arts and music initiative by young people, for young people" (https://www.hollandreno.org/about/). The portion painted by Burke depicts "George W. G. Ferris Jr. who grew up in the Nevada Capital and nearby city of Carson in 1870's...[and] entered notoriety after conceptualizing and engineering the Ferris Wheel for the 1893 World Fair in Chicago" (http://eriktburke.com/Holland-Project). Ferris Jr.'s cranium is exposed and transitions into the wheel he was called "the man with wheels in is head" for inventing (http://eriktburke.com/Holland-Project). The figures that flank Ferris Jr. (painted by Labrona) embody a cubist style of painting. Each of these figures wears an unorthodox hat: a house, and a goose. The background is composed of geometric shapes.

titleInfo.title: Unknown [Octopus, Peacock Feathers, Futuristic Head]; Unknown [The Melting Pot World Emporium]

subject.geographic: Southern wall of The Melting Pot World Emporium & Smoke Shop at 1049 S. Virginia St., Reno, NV

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. mods.abstract: This mural depicts a large brown octopus mixed with peacock feathers and a human-like figure. The octopus is the focus of the mural. The body of the octopus is painted in a palette of browns, while its suckers are painted in a palette of blue. The peacock feathers almost resemble the suckers as they intertwine into the octopus's tentacles. The tentacles wrap around and burst through a portrait of a blue human-like figure wearing headphones that emerges from the mud-cracked ground, perhaps representing Burning Man since the business upon which the mural is painted, The Melting Pot World Emporium, is one of the leading retailers of Playa gear in the area. The figure stares out into the distance. A tentacle bursts through the middle portrait, which depicts the Burning Man logo centered in the Burning-Man-Playa landscape with planets hanging in the night sky above. The last portrait is a circus-style wall sign for the The Melting Pot. A curtain opens up to a stage with silhouettes of people dancing in front of an earth with sun rays around it. The background of the entire mural is painted a bright red, contrasting the aquatic and desert ambiance of the subject matter.

mods.abstract: The front side of Ashley Follmer's signal-box mural depicts a woman wearing a light blue dress with her hands held behind her back. The section of the woman where her neck and head should be erupts into a huge cloud that transitions from dark orange on the left, to yellow, to white on the right. The woman is painted against a background that transitions from bright yellow at the bottom, to lime green, to a deeper green at the top. The subject of this mural might relate to its location on the University of Nevada, Reno campus: perhaps the figure's head is exploding from the knowledge it has acquired (as in, "mind blown!").

mods.abstract: This under-the-sea-themed mural was painted by artist Vaka on the exterior of Stingray Tattoo, where he works as a tattoo artist. Several dark blue stingrays swim throughout the mural that wraps around two adjacent walls on the northeast side of the tattoo parlor, covers the ceiling that overhangs the walls and spills into the pavement below. Two orange, white and black clown fish swim through some purple sea anemones and and light blue sponges that emerge from the bottom corner of the mural where the two walls meet. On the far right side (northern wall) of the mural, a massive ray swims towards some red coral that flanks a window. On the left side (eastern wall) of the mural, a word (possibly "Ink") is painted red and white in flourish font, while the same paint colors are used on the cinderblocks of the wall to create the illusion that the wall is breaking and falling into the sea; several of these broken blocks float throughout the mural.

mods.abstract: This mural is a three-part piece painted by artist Joe C. Rock. The potion of the fence here, which has since been torn down, portrays John Sparks. Sage brush grows horizontally from his face. On the far-right end of the fence is a depiction of the Nevada bicentennial coin. Barbed wire winds around the sagebrush on this side of the fence, and the golden-yellow banner from the Nevada state flag wraps around flows through the entire scene.

mods.abstract: Devin Hosselkus' signal-box mural depicts various individuals in a city-like setting (perhaps downtown Reno, given the location of the box just north of the Virginia Street Bridge over the Truckee River). In the foreground of the front side of the box is the profile of a person with gray hair and purple skin, wearing a green shirt and brown paints, apparently walking towards the left. In the background and what appears to be across the street, from left to right: a person wearing a white shirt and blue pants sits on a wooden bench; a man wearing a white tank tops looks across the street; a man with blue skin, wearing a white shirt and brown pants walks towards the left; a person wearing a maroon shirt walks in the opposite direction; a person wearing a white bandana, black shirt and gray pants has their back turned away from the viewer. A body of water (presumably the Truckee River) flows under a bridge and street lights behind and to the right of the person in the foreground. On the left side of the box, a street and crosswalk, with its wide white lines, is depicted. Two brown birds appear in the lower-right corner.

mods.abstract: This gypsy-like woman, painted by artist Anthony Ortega, fashions a combination of deep-red and golden-yellow hair, wrapped in a green and white gypsy headscarf, embellished with a vibrant yellow flower. She is also accented with dangling golden earrings, blue sleeves, and detailed floral designs on her shoulders. She holds a cocktail in her left hand, displaying her connection to Davidson's distillery, the place upon which the mural was painted.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)";

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "..people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/). He wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor.

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. mods.abstract: The theme of this vibrant mural, painted by members of UTI Crew during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, directly relates to the location in which it is painted: the wall of Headquarters Bar, a bar owned and operated by "Crawl Reno, the organizers of the Reno Zombie Crawl and a ton of other massive parties in downtown Reno" (http://headquartersreno.com/#home_about). On the right side of the mural stands a man with characteristics representative of the various crawls that take place in Reno throughout the year. The red Santa hat he wears with gold polka dots and a gold fur ball gestures towards the Santa Crawl; his green beard gestures towards the Leprechaun Crawl; and the Superman shirt he wears gestures towards the Super Hero Crawl. On the left side of the mural is a zombie with a mask resting on the top of its head, representing both the Zombie and Mardi Gras Crawls. These two figures flank four separate graffiti-style words (one of which appears to be the moniker of one of the UTI Crew members, Spek). In the background of the mural, a city skyline goes up in flames, perhaps caused by the man on the left who holds a lit match in his right hand, a mug of bear in his left. To the left of the mural is a small chain link fence with wood slats upon which "The Crawl" is painted in aqua, turquoise and sky blue horror font against a yellow and orange background with red splatters.

mods.abstract: This painted-wall sign welcomes those driving past it to Dickerson Road, an area west of downtown Reno, running parallel to the Truckee River, that is referred to as "'Reno’s Industrial Arts District,' combining art, commercial and residential properties, and a nature preserve." Using bright and vibrant colors, Eric (Erik) Burke and Buz Rhodes painted large block letters, with orange and red shadows behind them, to spell out "Dickerson," with imagery and scenes appearing in each letter that signify and represent the nature of the district. The "D" features an angle grinder cutting metal; a paint brush stands in for the "I"; the "C" features the profile of half of a sandwich; the "K" displays a smith forging a piece of metal; the "E" shows someone wearing tan pants and brown boots laying under the hood of a vehicle; the "R" features a woman's body in profile from her lower torso to the top of her knees, wearing a black and white striped undergarment, with red rose vines over the entire image; the "S" contains water with green and purple lily pads floating on top; the "O" is made up of a figure wearing tan garments throwing on a yellow pottery wheel; and the "N" includes a variety of multicolored metal bottle caps. The words "Welcome to" and "Live, Work, Eat, Play" appear in red and blue on a white banner painted on the left side of the mural. The artists' names,"Eric Burke and Buz Rhodes," appear in red and blue on a white banner painted in the upper far-right corner of the mural.

She holds a cocktail in her left hand, displaying her connection to Davidson's distillery, the place upon which the mural was painted.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains, his mural painted by Joe C. Rock during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 "featur[es] the arm of my mother stretched across 2nd St... representing her strength and commitment to diversity with her 65 year old freshly tattooed arm piece...I was raised by my mother my entire childhood in a single parent home, she did everything she could do to get me to make the right choices in life and did whatever she needed to do to provide the best life for my cousins, sister and myself, sacrificing her own needs for ours" (https://www.instagram.com/p/Bb-uzY6Dwyr/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13) & (https://www.instagram.com/p/BeL5LzdDuCN/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13).

mods.abstract: This under-the-sea-themed mural was painted by artist Vaka on the exterior of Stingray Tattoo, where he works as a tattoo artist. Several dark blue stingrays swim throughout the mural that wraps around two adjacent walls on the northeast side of the tattoo parlor, covers the ceiling that overhangs the walls and spills into the pavement below. Two orange, white and black clown fish swim through some purple sea anemones and and light blue sponges that emerge from the bottom corner of the mural where the two walls meet. On the far right side (northern wall) of the mural, a massive ray swims towards some red coral that flanks a window. On the left side (eastern wall) of the mural, a word (possibly "Ink") is painted red and white in flourish font, while the same paint colors are used on the cinderblocks of the wall to create the illusion that the wall is breaking and falling into the sea; several of these broken blocks float throughout the mural.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a large brown octopus mixed with peacock feathers and a human-like figure. The octopus is the focus of the mural. The body of the octopus is painted in a palette of browns, while its suckers are painted in a palette of blue. The peacock feathers almost resemble the suckers as they intertwine into the octopus's tentacles. The tentacles wrap around and burst through a portrait of a blue human-like figure wearing headphones that emerges from the mud-cracked ground, perhaps representing Burning Man since the business upon which the mural is painted, The Melting Pot World Emporium, is one of the leading retailers of Playa gear in the area. The figure stares out into the distance. A tentacle bursts through the middle portrait, which depicts the Burning Man logo centered in the Burning-Man-Playa landscape with planets hanging in the night sky above. The last portrait is a circus-style wall sign for the The Melting Pot. A curtain opens up to a stage with silhouettes of people dancing in front of an earth with sun rays around it. The background of the entire mural is painted a bright red, contrasting the aquatic and desert ambiance of the subject matter.

mods.abstract: The right side of this signal box painted by Vaka features the left side of a rodeo clown. The side of the white cowboy hat with red trim that the clown wears can be seen, as can the clown's ear, and a small portion of his neck, adorned with a red neckerchief, worn above a blue shirt with white stripes along the shoulders. Behind the clown is a multicolored background speckled with yellow, blue, red and green handprints. The theme of this signal box relates to its proximity to the Reno Livestock Events Center, the venue for the Reno Rodeo.

mods.abstract: In this painting, artist Jennifer Charboneau reinterprets Paul Cezanne's infamous modernist style painting, The Basket of Apples. Like Cezanne, Charboneau abstracts still-life painting by alluding to objects without defining their form. Charboneau uses shades of red, orange, yellow, blue, green, and white for this work. Lastly, Charboneau adds black font and her signature on the left side of work.

mods.abstract: Two smiling hispanic woman are depicted in this monochromatic mural installed by Dr. Chip Thomas during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. On the left, an older woman rests her head on the shoulder of a younger woman with her right hand raised to and resting on the right side of her face. On the older woman's cheek are the words "We Are Powerful" and on the left side of the younger woman's face, on her eyelid and cheek, are the words "No Somos Cien Somos Milliones Cuentanos Bien (We are not one. We Are not hundreds. We are millions. Count us well." The mural gestures towards the presence and vital role of the hispanic community in the U.S.

mods.abstract: The theme of this vibrant mural, painted by members of UTI Crew during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, directly relates to the location in which it is painted: the wall of Headquarters Bar, a bar owned and operated by "Crawl Reno, the organizers of the Reno Zombie Crawl and a ton of other massive parties in downtown Reno" (http://headquartersreno.com/#home_about). On the right side of the mural stands a man with characteristics representative of the various crawls that take place in Reno throughout the year. The red Santa hat he wears with gold polka dots and a gold fur ball gestures towards the Santa Crawl; his green beard gestures towards the Leprechaun Crawl; and the Superman shirt he wears gestures towards the Super Hero Crawl. On the left side of the mural is a zombie with a mask resting on the top of its head, representing both the Zombie and Mardi Gras Crawls. These two figures flank four separate graffiti-style words (one of which appears to be the moniker of one of the UTI Crew members, Spek). In the background of the mural, a city skyline goes up in flames, perhaps caused by the man on the left who holds a lit match in his right hand, a mug of bear in his left. To the left of the mural is a small chain link fence with wood slats upon which "The Crawl" is painted in aqua, turquoise and sky blue horror font against a yellow and orange background with red splatters.

mods.abstract: Five panels of this wall were painted by five different artists during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. The three here were painted by artists Rafael Blanco, Hernan Borrero and Bryce Chishol. Blanco paints an elderly woman wearing an dark-green head covering with an American flag superimposed on her face. The woman is painted against a black background with translucent white splatters around her; Borrero paints an animated bindle-carrying dog smoking in front of an idle motel located in the southwestern desert, suggested by the magenta cacti. The mural is painted in shades of green, pink, purple, yellow, black, and brown; Chisholm's mural features a a vibrant multicolored background. A young woman on the right and a wolf below her on the left have been painted over the background using a stencil (a technique the artist is known for) and black and white paint. Two thin lines with stars surrounding them encircled the woman. A thin white outline of the number 4 (for 4th Street, where the building upon which the mural resides), surrounded by a blue flourish pattern, are painted in the upper-left side of the mural. An aqua-blue houndstooth pattern has been painted (again, with a stencil) in the upper-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural set against a light blue background depicts a camera with a roll of film unraveling from its film compartment. On the unraveled film can be seen the undeveloped images that the camera has captured. A girl holds her dog; a man hangs out the driver-side window of a van and looks at the camera; a man kneels in front of his bicycle; two children ride their bicycles; a man looks to his left with a city street behind him; a man holds two bags (one in each hand) up in the air and smiles at the camera; a woman stands with her hands in her pockets and smiles at the camera; a young girl looks quizzically at the camera; a young man looks back at the camera from the driver-side window of his car; a man stands with his hands in his pockets in front of a light pole; a man with a thick mustache looks directly at the camera, a skull-like object is to the left of him; four children sit together on some steps; a young girl rides a rocking horse. The film roll ends, leading into an orange burst and then beam of light that perhaps represents the light needed to expose the film. The light beam is surrounded by black, blue, and gray clouds.

Floating in the middle of and above the plot is a large red heart, the inside exposed from the middle down. Plants with red stems grow out of the top of the heart, their roots grow out of the bottom. The plants and their roots by be representative of arteries.

mods.abstract: Five panels of this wall were painted by five different artists during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. The three here are by artists Lisa Kurt, Joshua Coffy, and Jamie Darragh. Kurt paints a black fox standing in a meadow within a forest landscape. Surrounding the fox are trees, bushes, tumbleweed and a ghost. Kurt uses yellow, orange, green, black, and white to paint this mural; Coffy's mural features a black bear with ryukin fish swimming around it. The bottom third of the mural's background is an aegean-blue color, perhaps representative of water, while the rest of the background is tan with chiffon circles (or bubbles). A grid of eleven colors has been painted in the top middle of the mural; An aqua-blue alien head with bulbous black eyes painted against a black background is the subject of Darragh's mural. The alien's head is adorned with a metallic-gold head piece with nine graduated white circles centered above. Three different metallic-gold medallions float behind the alien head and seven different moon phases are depicted above the alien's head. Metallic gold appears at the very top of the mural. Darragh's Instagram handle, @j.darragh.art, is painted in metallic gold on the bottom-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). This portrait is of Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley, as symbolized by the brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of his head.

mods.abstract: This signal-box mural by Devin Hosselkus is Reno themed. Reno's slogan,"Reno: the Biggest Little City in the World," wraps around the box, as do renderings of the various versions of the Reno arches (the original version with slogan: installed in 1929; the second version: installed in 1963; and the current version: installed in 1987). Hosselkus used a simple color palette consisting of navy blue, teal, red, tan and brown, grey, white, and black.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe, explaining the basket behind the top of her head.

mods.abstract: Erik Burke painted this mural for Morgan's Lobster Shack and Fish Market, explaining the lobster in the middle of the mural against a background of blue ocean water that transitions to dark and then a lighter gray above, with nine buoys floating at the top of the mural. The buoys are painted a variety of colors (from left to right): white on a black rope; gold on a natural rope; black, yellow, and robin's-egg-blue striped on a black rope; red on a natural rope; pink on a natural rope; teal, white and red on a natural rope; pink on a natural rope; white and dark purple striped on a black rope; and black, white and red striped on a black rope. The lobster has been painted using several shades of orange and black, but the details of and sheen on the lobster was created using a variety of unexpected colors: sky, cerulean and periwinkle blue; yellow; peach; fern and crocodile green; lavender and iris purple; and red. Burke's moniker (OU38) and website (eriktburke.com) are painted in light blue on the bottom-left corner. The mural is 24 x 44 ft.

mods.abstract: Artist Bryce Chisholm painted this "Super Boy" on his 16 x 20 foot panel of the Nevada Fine Arts wall using a stencil (a technique Chisholm is known for). Outfitted in a red and black cape and mask, with a star emblazoned on his chest, the boy strikes a heroic pose against a colorful background of various geometric shapes and patterns. Flying pigeons speckle the mural, while one is perched in the upper-left corner.

mods.abstract: The front of Michael Lucido's electric-box mural features a skateboarding raccoon wearing 3D glasses. The raccoon's mouth is so wide open you can see its uvula, its tongue hangs out and is wind-blown towards that back of his head, as is saliva. The raccoon rides an aqua-blue skateboard with pink wheels against a turquoise background, grasping the board with its right hand as it does a trick, its left arm is raised high in the air. The skateboarding theme of this box possibly relates to its location at City Park Plaza, used in the past as an unofficial skate park.

mods.abstract: At 28 x 140 ft., Erik Burke's mural, Camouflage, is the largest painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. The mural abstracts images such as a pioneer woman on riding a horse, cacti, and sheep that represent Nevada's historical past as well as its promising future. The top of the mural reads "Look to the Pasture to see the Future," conveying the influence that the natural landscape, farming and ranching has had in this state.

mods.abstract: In this mural, artist Anthony Ortega paints a bright owl with super powers roaming the night. The owl is painted in shades of pink, orange, purple, red, beige, and green; it is draped with a blue cloak with geometric shapes. The owl has green light rays beaming from its eyes into the bottom right corner of the mural. The sky is painted in dark blues and black with swirling white clouds. The style of the mural pays homage to Japanese anime, referenced through the animated owl, it's wardrobe, it's "super power," and the anime-style clouds.

mods.abstract: The focal point of Bryce Chisholm's electric-box mural is the profile of a girl holding an umbrella with her face resting in the palm of her right hand as she looks down at the ground. She is painted in black and white, using a stencil (a technique Chisholm is known for). Her striped tights are light blue and black. She stands against a purple background. Puffy white rain clouds outlined in red and pouring red rain drops surround the girl. The background is speckled with yellow, blue, and pink dashes, lines, and brushstrokes. On the left side of the box, from the middle up, is a white stenciled geometric pattern. The original green color of the box shows through certain areas. Chisholm's moniker (ABC) is painted in white on the lower-left corner of the box.

mods.abstract: The focal point of artist Seth McCorkle's signal-box mural is the mountain chickadee, common in the mountains of Nevada. On the back side of the box, a single dickadee is perched on a branch of a plant or tree, with a little green foliage on it. A cerulean-blue body of water appears in the background, with a light blue sky with fluffy-white clouds above. McCorkle's moniker and the date are painted in light blue on the bottom-left corner of the box.

mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural set against a light blue background depicts a camera with a roll of film unraveling from its film compartment. On the unraveled film can be seen the undeveloped images that the camera has captured. A girl holds her dog; a man hangs out the driver-side window of a van and looks at the camera; a man kneels in front of his bicycle; two children ride their bicycles; a man looks to his left with a city street behind him; a man holds two bags (one in each hand) up in the air and smiles at the camera; a woman stands with her hands in her pockets and smiles at the camera; a young girl looks quizzically at the camera; a young man looks back at the camera from the driver-side window of his car; a man stands with his hands in his pockets in front of a light pole; a man with a thick mustache looks directly at the camera, a skull-like object is to the left of him; four children sit together on some steps; a young girl rides a rocking horse. The film roll ends, leading into an orange burst and then beam of light that perhaps represents the light needed to expose the film. The light beam is surrounded by black, blue, and gray clouds.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock combines United States history with the history of Nevada in this mural that was commissioned to celebrate the Historic Lincoln Highway. Abraham Lincoln appears on the left side of the mural, leading to the Nevada flag and then U.S. flag, over which the words "LINCOLN HIGHWAY" are painted in different font styles and are flanked by the Nevada flag and the Interstate 40 highway sign. All subjects combined, this mural conveys the relevance of this president and his namesake highway.

subject.geographic: Eastern wall of a detached garage behind a house at 22 W. Taylor St., Reno, NV

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. Please refer to the organization that has made the item available for more information. You are free to use this item in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. http://rightsstatements.org/vocab/UND/1.0/
mods.abstract: The theme of the mural on this detached garage, painted by Joe C. Rock, relates to its location behind Marmot Properties, one of the foremost real estate development companies in Reno that is particularly active in the Midtown area. The entire structure is painted bright green. On the east-facing wall is a monochromatic scene of three marmots behind some plants with the words "Things Change" painted in white over the scene. A crown hangs over the "i" in "things." The words are transparent and reveal what is behind them, except the "thi" in "things," which reveal a house and fence. The marmots on this wall represent Marmot Properties, while "Things Change" and the house and fence scene contained in the "thi" gestures towards Marmot's role in transforming the area's landscape, demography and culture through their development activities.

mods.abstract: Anthony Ortega won the 2017 24-Hour Mural Marathon competition with a psychedelic mural composition that combines ancient Mesoamerican art with futuristic elements. This mural is painted with vibrant shades of blue, red, green, orange, yellow, pink, and purple, portraying a vivid ancient Mesoamerican god-like figure that emerges from the stellar depths of the galaxy behind it and begins its descent into the green forest that surrounds the outer edges of the mural.

record.Title: Energy Mask
record.Description: Anthony Ortega won the 2017 24-Hour Mural Marathon competition with a psychedelic mural composition that combines ancient Mesoamerican art with futuristic elements. This mural is painted with vibrant shades of blue, red, green, orange, yellow, pink, and purple, portraying a vivid ancient Mesoamerican god-like figure that emerges from the stellar depths of the galaxy behind it and begins its descent into the green forest that surrounds the outer edges of the mural.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.abstract: A Buddha-like figure with three eyes, the middle of which has green and magenta rays beaming from it towards the sky, is the focal point of this mural by Garrison Buxton. A rainbow of colors emerge from the figure's mouth, eventually casting an orange and lavender background upon which the phrase "Thoughts Are Things" is painted in white. The yin-and-yang symbol hangs on a green necklace around the figure's neck, below which the phrase "Know Thy Self" appears on a banner across the figure's torso. To the right of the figure, the phrase "Be Kind" is painted in white against a periwinkle background. Buxton's moniker is painted in metallic gold on the bottom-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: A fluid mural is painted by artist Joe C. Rock on this three-sided fence. The mural begins with the head of a woman in front of clouds whose hair then flows throughout the mural, as do the clouds. An array of subject matter appear among the hair and clouds over a light-blue background. While some figures portray recognizable figures, such as dice, eye balls, power lines, butterflies, rain drops, a bee, a rose, a mountain range, and botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern), other subjects and figures are more abstract, or focus on written text.

mods.abstract: Devin Hosselkus' signal-box mural depicts various individuals in a city-like setting (perhaps downtown Reno, given the location of the box just north of the Virginia Street Bridge over the Truckee River). On the back side of the box is a man with white hair and a gray beard, wearing a dark blue shirt and tan pants. To his left is a large pot with white, red, and purple flowers. Another pot with white flowers hangs from a metal post.

mods.abstract: Artist Erik Burke painted this beer-and-wine themed 45 x 18 foot mural to coincide with the business upon which it resides, Craft Wine and Beer. Dark brown beer bottles and green and pink wine bottles, all with various labels, are painted against a cerulean-blue background. The bottles are painted in a repeating pattern wherein either: one bottle faces right-way up while another is turned upside down with a stream beer or wine flowing between the mouths of the bottles; or one bottle faces right-way up while the other is turned upside and the bases of bottles rest on each other. The largest bottle and focal point of the mural is a beer bottle with a monochromatic label depicting a hops farmer and that reads "Craft Wine Beer."

mods.abstract: The front side of Cathy Ashworth's signal-box mural portrays Reno pride. In the center of the work lies a red heart with a banner across it that reads "Reno." Like the back of the box, fire also arises from the heart and the Burning Man logo appears in the main flame. The background is then divided into sections that depict scenery relating to northern Nevada. On the left side of the box, a red heart arise from the ground, as if it were a plant. The fire atop the heart gravitates towards the vibrant yellow sun.

mods.abstract: In this collaborative piece painted by Erik Burke, Kelly Peyton, and Kaitlyn Bryson, a male figure wearing dark blue jeans and a yellow tank top lays on his back in front of a blue background with hands interlaced and resting on his stomach. It appears as though the man is floating. In the bottom-left corner of the mural, circular, triangular, other geometric shapes, and dashes are painted on the man's pants in a shade of blue lighter than the pants and more like that of the background. Similar shapes are painted in marigold yellow on the man's shirt, as are figures fashioned out of the letters "L" and "D" and the number "4" (L4, D4); these figures represent the phrase "Live for What You Would Die For." These figures, and the phrase they represent, likely relate to the theme and purpose of the mural, referred to by one if its painters, Burke, as a tribute to Beau Shaver of Reno, NV who is also likely the man depicted in the mural. The man also has various shapes (hearts, roses, the outline of a crown) and words painted in yellow on his arm, neck, face and teeth. The background of the right side of the mural is painted in graduated shades of blue (light to dark, from the bottom to the top). An upside down brown hat appears in the lower-right corner of the mural, it has currant-red-outlined-in-yellow flowers sitting on the brim and one flower peaking out from inside. Burke's moniker (OU33), the other two artists' initials (KP and Kb), and the date (2012) are painted in white in the upper-right corner of the mural, with "L4D4 SODC SHAVER" painted below. The mural is 80 x 16 ft.

mods.abstract: According to the artist of this monochromatic mural, Joe C. Rock, "I initially painted this because I walked by this door daily and it had an 'I smoke meth' tag...on [it] for a month. I took the initiative and painted a portrait in the likeness of J.F.K. as a child over it [and] the man who owns the building liked it and it's been there ever since""(https://www.instagram.com/p/BJPRYGMhqZK/?taken-by=joecrock13). The young JFK wears a striped shirt and the outline of a small gold crown (not present at the time this photograph was taken) sits atop his head.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a large brown octopus mixed with peacock feathers and a human-like figure. The octopus is the focus of the mural. The body of the octopus is painted in a palette of browns, while its suckers are painted in a palette of blue. The peacock feathers almost resemble the suckers as they intertwine into the octopus's tentacles. The tentacles wrap around and burst through a portrait of a blue human-like figure wearing headphones that emerges from the mud-cracked ground, perhaps representing Burning Man since the business upon which the mural is painted, The Melting Pot World Emporium, is one of the leading retailers of Playa gear in the area. The figure stares out into the distance. A tentacle bursts through the middle portrait, which depicts the Burning Man logo centered in the Burning-Man-Playa landscape with planets hanging in the night sky above. The last portrait is a circus-style wall sign for the The Melting Pot. A curtain opens up to a stage with silhouettes of people dancing in front of an earth with sun rays around it. The background of the entire mural is painted a bright red, contrasting the aquatic and desert ambiance of the subject matter.

mods.abstract: "DAYDREAM!" appears in all caps in this mural that artist Joe C. Rock painted on a chain link fence with wood slats. Enclosed within the block letters is green grass against a blue skyline. The letters are outlined in white and cast red shadows outlined in peach. Growing out of the grass in the first "D" is a blue flower. A butterfly with blue wings perches on the outside edge of the second "D" and a lady bug crawls across the grass. A red rose rests on the left side of the "R." A worm slithers through the grass, straddling the right side of the "R" and left side of the "E," disappearing and re-emerging out of the right side of the "E." A blue flower with a lady bug on it grows out of the grass in the dot of the exclamation point.

record.Title: Daydream
record.Description: "DAYDREAM!" appears in all caps in this mural that artist Joe C. Rock painted on a chain link fence with wood slats. Enclosed within the block letters is green grass against a blue skyline. The letters are outlined in white and cast red shadows outlined in peach. Growing out of the grass in the first "D" is a blue flower. A butterfly with blue wings perches on the outside edge of the second "D" and a lady bug crawls across the grass. A red rose rests on the left side of the "R." A worm slithers through the grass, straddling the right side of the "R" and left side of the "E," disappearing and re-emerging out of the right side of the "E." A blue flower with a lady bug on it grows out of the grass in the dot of the exclamation point.
record.Sitelocation: North-facing fence in back of house at 221 Moran St., Reno, NV

mods.abstract: This mural painted on the Sutro Motel depicts the Sutro Tunnel: "a drainage tunnel (adit) connected to the Comstock Lode in Northern Nevada. It begins at Virginia City, Nevada and empties approximately 6 miles southeast near the town of Dayton, Nevada" (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sutro_Tunnel). A mule-drawn mine cart with people riding in it emerges from the tunnel on a mine railway that leads to a shirtless thickly-mustached man (perhaps Adolf Sutro, the engineer of the tunnel) holding a lantern. To the left of the tunnel is the word "Comstock," behind which a banner begins and flows across the mural and into a flourish design in the lower-right corner of the mural. The words "Battle Born" appear on the banner over the right shoulder of the man and the words "Silver State" appear on the portion of the banner that flows around and flanks the mine railway. Over the man's left shoulder, "$1,000" is painted in a gray bubble in front of the banner.

mods.abstract: This under-the-sea-themed mural was painted by artist Vaka on the exterior of Stingray Tattoo, where he works as a tattoo artist. Several dark blue stingrays swim throughout the mural that wraps around two adjacent walls on the northeast side of the tattoo parlor, covers the ceiling that overhangs the walls and spills into the pavement below. Two orange, white and black clown fish swim through some purple sea anemones and and light blue sponges that emerge from the bottom corner of the mural where the two walls meet. On the far right side (northern wall) of the mural, a massive ray swims towards some red coral that flanks a window. On the left side (eastern wall) of the mural, a word (possibly "Ink") is painted red and white in flourish font, while the same paint colors are used on the cinderblocks of the wall to create the illusion that the wall is breaking and falling into the sea; several of these broken blocks float throughout the mural.

mods.abstract: This wheat-paste mural, installed by Dr. Chip Thomas during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 portrays the face of a woman with a black mask painted over her eyes, the words "I Am The Change" across appear her forehead, and "Industrialization, Pollution, Drought, Water, Air, Earth, Fake Snow, CO2" appear across here cheeks, nose, upper lip and chin. As Thomas explains, the mural contains a message about the environment, climate change, and social responsibility, and the word "snow," specifically, "...references the snow bowl ski resort in flagstaff using reclaimed waste water to make fake snow on a mountain sacred to 13 different area tribes" (https://www.instagram.com/p/BefEAalAHkS/?hl=en&taken-by=jetsonorama).

mods.abstract: These three murals were painted by different artists on the back wall of the Potentialist Workshop, "a multidisciplinary collaborative arts collective in Reno, Nevada...The Potentialist Gallery is a space for innovative and experimental art by artists creating and exploring multiple artistic platforms"(http://www.potentialistworkshop.com/). On the left, artist Asa Kennedy paints a foreground of individual cubes, perhaps representing cracked pavement, comprised of purple, yellow, and green brush strokes. The cubes begin to float towards the sky in the middle of the composition. The foreground parts in the middle, revealing a dark-purple flower with a bright-orange center. Behind the flower is a light-purple plain with dark-purple mountains on the horizon. Above, white and purple clouds swirl around a blue sky and merge with the rising cubes. The middle mural depicts a white dairy cow with black spots raising her head to the bright-blue sky with fluffy white clouds, a bell on a red collar hangs around her neck. A pig with white spots, a piggy-bank slot on its back, and a yellow crown on its head stands in front of the cow's left-front quarter, facing the opposite direction. A rendering of a brick building appears oddly in the middle of the composition (where a window with a brick ledge naturally existed), with a cardinal perched on the right corner. The mural on the right depicts a monochromatic woman with hair comprised of roses coifed into an afro. She brings her right arm under her left, wrapping it around her torso. Painted on the step leading to the roller door to the left of the woman is a red tunnel with concentric black circles and blue, yellow and red circles floating in it, perhaps representing a galaxy with planets in orbit. A blue snake-like figure slithers through the tunnel. What appears to be the teeth of the lower jaw of an animal are portrayed in the lower foreground of the composition, perhaps suggesting that the the tunnel is mouth.

mods.abstract: This mural painted by artist Joe C. Rock represents the city of Reno, as well as the Statewide Lighting & Accents company (where the mural resides). The center of the mural highlights a large brightly-lit light bulb with a crown (a common object in Rock's paintings) sitting at the top. Behind the light bulb, the city's well-known "Reno" sign hides, acknowledging the brightness of the rising city. The word "BRIGHT" is also woven within the mural behind leaves and orange circles. Underneath the light bulb, the ground from which the bulb rises is visible; the word "IDEAS" is written through a depiction of stones.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock depicts a cowboy riding a wild mustang into the sunset, representative of the Reno Rodeo, in this mural painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. A halo of barbed wire floats above the cowboy's hat and a locomotive disguises itself in the body of the mustang. The background is painted bright blue with a beige banner swirling across it that reads "Get Buck Get Broke." Objects, such as grape bundles, crowns (a common object in Rock's murals), hearts and cherries speckle the mural's background.

mods.abstract: Artist Hernan Borrero paints an animated bindle-carrying dog smoking in front of an idle motel located in the southwestern desert, suggested by the magenta cacti. The mural is painted in shades of green, pink, purple, yellow, black, and brown. Bryce Chisholm's mural features a a vibrant multicolored background. A young woman on the right and a wolf below her on the left have been painted over the background using a stencil (a technique the artist is known for) and black and white paint. Two thin lines with stars surrounding them encircled the woman. A thin white outline of the number 4 (for 4th Street, where the building upon which the mural resides), surrounded by a blue flourish pattern, are painted in the upper-left side of the mural. A aqua-blue houndstooth pattern has been painted, again with a stencil in the upper-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: In this collaborative piece painted by Erik Burke, Kelly Peyton, and Kaitlyn Bryson, a male figure wearing dark blue jeans and a yellow tank top lays on his back in front of a blue background with hands interlaced and resting on his stomach. It appears as though the man is floating. In the bottom-left corner of the mural, circular, triangular, other geometric shapes, and dashes are painted on the man's pants in a shade of blue lighter than the pants and more like that of the background. Similar shapes are painted in marigold yellow on the man's shirt, as are figures fashioned out of the letters "L" and "D" and the number "4" (L4, D4); these figures represent the phrase "Live for What You Would Die For." These figures, and the phrase they represent, likely relate to the theme and purpose of the mural, referred to by one if its painters, Burke, as a tribute to Beau Shaver of Reno, NV who is also likely the man depicted in the mural. The man also has various shapes (hearts, roses, the outline of a crown) and words painted in yellow on his arm, neck, face and teeth. The background of the right side of the mural is painted in graduated shades of blue (light to dark, from the bottom to the top). An upside down brown hat appears in the lower-right corner of the mural, it has currant-red-outlined-in-yellow flowers sitting on the brim and one flower peaking out from inside. Burke's moniker (OU33), the other two artists' initials (KP and Kb), and the date (2012) are painted in white in the upper-right corner of the mural, with "L4D4 SODC SHAVER" painted below. The mural is 80 x 16 ft.

record.Title: Unknown [Beau Shaver Tribute]
record.Description: In this collaborative piece painted by Erik Burke, Kelly Peyton, and Kaitlyn Bryson, a male figure wearing dark blue jeans and a yellow tank top lays on his back in front of a blue background with hands interlaced and resting on his stomach. It appears as though the man is floating. In the bottom-left corner of the mural, circular, triangular, other geometric shapes, and dashes are painted on the man's pants in a shade of blue lighter than the pants and more like that of the background. Similar shapes are painted in marigold yellow on the man's shirt, as are figures fashioned out of the letters "L" and "D" and the number "4" (L4, D4); these figures represent the phrase "Live for What You Would Die For." These figures, and the phrase they represent, likely relate to the theme and purpose of the mural, referred to by one if its painters, Burke, as a tribute to Beau Shaver of Reno, NV who is also likely the man depicted in the mural. The man also has various shapes (hearts, roses, the outline of a crown) and words painted in yellow on his arm, neck, face and teeth. The background of the right side of the mural is painted in graduated shades of blue (light to dark, from the bottom to the top). An upside down brown hat appears in the lower-right corner of the mural, it has currant-red-outlined-in-yellow flowers sitting on the brim and one flower peaking out from inside. Burke's moniker (OU33), the other two artists' initials (KP and Kb), and the date (2012) are painted in white in the upper-right corner of the mural, with "L4D4 SODC SHAVER" painted below. The mural is 80 x 16 ft.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.abstract: This mural painted by artist Joshua Coffy during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017 features a black bear with ryukin goldfish swimming around it. The bottom third of the mural's background is an aegean-blue color, perhaps representative of water, while the rest of the background is tan with chiffon circles (or bubbles). A grid of eleven colors has been painted in the top middle of the mural.

mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural, originally painted for Lulu's Chic Boutique (now Timeless Fashion Consignment Shop and Bridal Salon) by artist Joe C. Rock, consists of a variety of geometric shapes, designs, patterns, and objects. The top portion of the mural is comprised of black polka dots. Water or mountains (what is actually the hair of a woman painted on the adjacent right or east-facing wall) flows from from the right, rising and then encircling the business logo painted in the center of the wall with the moon rising above it to the left. The logo is flanked on the left by the Eiffel Tower and on the right by the profile of a monocle-wearing man with a curly handlebar mustache whose top hat is the Leaning Tower of Pisa. Centered below the logo is an ornate fleurs-de-lis flanked by botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern). More fleurs-de-lis and botehs, as well as another top-hat-wearing figure, diamonds, various-sized squares, circles/dots, and flourish patterns speckle the left side of the mural. Rock brings a little color into the far-left side of the mural (under the window), where he has painted his moniker and some red dots (a few also appear to the left of and above the window). The right (east-facing) wall features the profile of a woman with red lips and a bright-pink rose in the zebra-pattern-like hair that flows behind her (and into the adjacent wall). She wears a pearl necklace and earrings, and pearls are threaded through her hair. To the right of the woman is a gray, black, white, and bright-red flourish design with botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern). Bright-red polka dots permeate from the design, creating the background of the entire composition. The dots get darker the further away from the design they get, until they eventually turn black.

mods.abstract: This mural is a three-part piece painted by artist Joe C. Rock. The fence here (of three total) depicts a hand-drawn rudimentary map representing Sparks, Reno, Virginia City and Carson City, Nevada. The sage brush that grows horizontally behind the map peaks through holes in the map and the golden-yellow banner from the Nevada state flag wraps around and through the entire seen. A monochromatic portrait of Kit Carson is painted on the-right side of the fence.

mods.abstract: The words "Positively 4th Street" are painted horizontally across a black wall with salmon, yellow and sky-blue geometric shapes painted over it. "Positively" and "street" are painted in different fonts, but both in white with a thin black outline. The "4" in "4th" is painted red with a white center and turquoise and yellow highlights in an ornate old-fashioned font, and the "th" is painted black in a simple font. The text message in this mural,"Positively 4th Street," represents "a re-branding campaign for E. 4th Street in Reno, NV. One annual event a year showcases the changing atmosphere of the neighborhood and highlights the young, creative, motivated small business owners guiding the effort"(https://www.facebook.com/events/316484078500029/).

mods.abstract: The theme of the mural on this detached garage, painted by Joe C. Rock, relates to its location behind Marmot Properties, one of the foremost real estate development companies in Reno, particularly active in the Midtown area. The entire structure is painted bright green. On the front of the garage is the head of a person with their hair covering their face, their right hand cups the lower part of their face. Reno's downtown skyline comprises the top of the head with Mount Rose at its apex. A red and gold crown (a common object in Rock's murals) with a halo of barbed wire floats above the head. On the garage door, the words "The Heart of the City"(with a heart above the "i" in "city") are painted over the head in red with a neon-green outline. Pink hearts appear on the portion of the letters that extend past the head, and the portion covering the head is transparent, revealing imagery behind it. The door is framed by branches of sagebrush and the shadows they cast. "The Heart of the City" might symbolize the centrality of the Midtown district in the greater Reno area, both geographically and culturally. On the east-facing wall of the garage is a monochromatic scene of three marmots behind some plants with the words "Things Change" painted in white over the scene. A crown hangs over the "i" in "things." The words are transparent and reveal what is behind them, except the "thi" in "things," which reveal a house and fence. The marmots on this wall represent Marmot Properties, while "Things Change" and the house and fence scene contained in the "thi" gestures towards Marmot's role in transforming the area's landscape, demography and culture through their development activities.

mods.accessCondition: The copyright and related rights status of this item has been reviewed by the organization that has made the item available, but the organization was unable to make a conclusive determination as to the copyright status of the item. mods.abstract: The two roller doors of the Reno Fire Department station in downtown Reno each depict different fire helmets. On the right door is a black leather (likely) helmet with a brass eagle adornment affixed to the top of the helmet that secures a leather shield that reads "Reno Fire Firefighter Truck 1" to the front helmet front. The crown (an object that appears in many of Rock's murals) on the eagle's head is not found on actual helmets. Smoke emerges from behind the helmet. In the lower-right corner of the door is a monochromatic scene depicting a firefighter manning the deluge gun on top of a fire engine. On the left third of the door is another monochromatic scene depicting one of two firefighters (or one split in half by the wall between the two doors) fully suited up and wearing a helmet with respirator while three people climb a ladder in the background to the right.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a large brown octopus mixed with peacock feathers and a human-like figure. The octopus is the focus of the mural. The body of the octopus is painted in a palette of browns, while its suckers are painted in a palette of blue. The peacock feathers almost resemble the suckers as they intertwine into the octopus's tentacles. The tentacles wrap around and burst through a portrait of a blue human-like figure wearing headphones that emerges from the mud-cracked ground, perhaps representing Burning Man since the business upon which the mural is painted, The Melting Pot World Emporium, is one of the leading retailers of Playa gear in the area. The figure stares out into the distance. A tentacle bursts through the middle portrait, which depicts the Burning Man logo centered in the Burning-Man-Playa landscape with planets hanging in the night sky above. The last portrait is a circus-style wall sign for the The Melting Pot. A curtain opens up to a stage with silhouettes of people dancing in front of an earth with sun rays around it. The background of the entire mural is painted a bright red, contrasting the aquatic and desert ambiance of the subject matter.

mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural set against a light blue background depicts a camera with a roll of film unraveling from its film compartment. On the unraveled film can be seen the undeveloped images that the camera has captured. A girl holds her dog; a man hangs out the driver-side window of a van and looks at the camera; a man kneels in front of his bicycle; two children ride their bicycles; a man looks to his left with a city street behind him; a man holds two bags (one in each hand) up in the air and smiles at the camera; a woman stands with her hands in her pockets and smiles at the camera; a young girl looks quizzically at the camera; a young man looks back at the camera from the driver-side window of his car; a man stands with his hands in his pockets in front of a light pole; a man with a thick mustache looks directly at the camera, a skull-like object is to the left of him; four children sit together on some steps; a young girl rides a rocking horse. The film roll ends, leading into an orange burst and then beam of light that perhaps represents the light needed to expose the film. The light beam is surrounded by black, blue, and gray clouds.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. This portrait is of Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects. The buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head symbolize his career as an architect.

mods.abstract: Two smiling hispanic woman are depicted in this monochromatic mural installed by Dr. Chip Thomas during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. On the left, an older woman rests her head on the shoulder of a younger woman with her right hand raised to and resting on the right side of her face. On the older woman's cheek are the words "We Are Powerful" and on the left side of the younger woman's face, on her eyelid and cheek, are the words "No Somos Cien Somos Milliones Cuentanos Bien (We are not one. We Are not hundreds. We are millions. Count us well." The mural gestures towards the presence and vital role of the hispanic community in the U.S.

mods.abstract: A fluid mural is painted by artist Joe C. Rock on this three-sided fence. The mural begins with the head of a woman in front of clouds whose hair then flows throughout the mural, as do the clouds. An array of subject matter appear among the hair and clouds over a light-blue background. While some figures portray recognizable figures, such as dice, eye balls, power lines, butterflies, rain drops, a bee, a rose, a mountain range, and botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern), other subjects and figures are more abstract, or focus on written text.

mods.abstract: According to artist Joe C. Rock, his mural on the exterior wall of the Renaissance Reno Downtown Hotel "depicts imagery of Reno and the greater-Nevada area. The octagon 'R' is from the second Reno arch that ran from 1963-1987 [and] the background is filled with sage, our state flower. The 'E' is filled with a mountain bluebird, our state bird. The 'N' is inside a silver state of Nevada with a portrait of Jesse Reno, our city's namesake. The 'O' is from the current Reno arch [and sits over] a heart, inside the 'O' is a landscape of Mt. Rose surrounded by a red rose. The piece is finished off with the words 'Home Means Nevada,' our state song" (https://www.instagram.com/p/BUS8FaqDbF4/?hl=en&taken-by=joecrock13).

mods.abstract: This mural is a three-part piece painted by artist Joe C. Rock. The potion of the fence here, which has since been torn down, portrays John Sparks. Sage brush grows horizontally from his face. On the far-right end of the fence is a depiction of the Nevada bicentennial coin. Barbed wire winds around the sagebrush on this side of the fence, and the golden-yellow banner from the Nevada state flag wraps around flows through the entire scene.

mods.abstract: This mural, originally painted for Lulu's Chic Boutique (now Timeless Fashion Consignment Shop and Bridal Salon) by artist Joe C. Rock, features the profile of a woman with red lips and a bright-pink rose in the zebra-pattern-like hair that flows behind her (and into the adjacent wall). She wears a pearl necklace and earrings, and pearls are threaded through her hair. To the right of the woman is a gray, black, white, and bright-red flourish design with botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern). Bright-red polka dots permeate from the design, creating the background of the entire composition. The dots get darker the further away from the design they get, until they eventually turn black.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.abstract: The back side of this signal box painted by Vaka features young child riding a sheep or, mutton busting. The boy wears a large beige cowboy hat, a blue shirt with white dots, a gray vest with the letter "A" in black over a yellow circle, and blue jeans. Pennies have been glued (not by the artist) to the child's and sheep's eyes and the child's nostrils. The theme of this signal box relates to its proximity to the Reno Livestock Events Center, the venue for the Reno Rodeo.

mods.abstract: This 65 x (roughly) 16 foot mural pinated on the wall of Peerless Cleaners by artist Erik Burke combines Reno history and Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is speckled with small symbols that depict prominent Reno figures, organizations, and locations in the business's and city's history. Some of these symbols are connected, like constellations, by a line that carries throughout the composition. The mountain-range landscape can also be interpreted as draped fabric, connecting the mural to the the business located in that building. The mural is painted in shades of red, orange, yellow, blue and white.

mods.abstract: At 28 x 140 ft., Erik Burke's mural, Camouflage, is the largest painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017. The mural abstracts images such as a pioneer woman on riding a horse, cacti, and sheep that represent Nevada's historical past as well as its promising future. The top of the mural reads "Look to the Pasture to see the Future," conveying the influence that the natural landscape, farming and ranching has had in this state.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.

record.Title: Nevada; Nevada Row
record.Description: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits, spanning the entire 250 x 20 foot mural. The portraits, from left to right, are as follows: Frederic DeLongchamps, one of Nevada's most prolific architects; Dot So La Lee, a basket weaver and member of the northwestern Nevada Washoe; Wovoka, a Paiute religious leader; Ben Palmer, one of the original settlers of and most successful ranchers in the Carson Valley; Michael Heizer, a contemporary artist whose life-long project, City, is "the largest piece of contemporary art ever attempted" (http://doublenegative.tarasen.net/city/)"; Jeanne Wier, founder of the Nevada Historical Society; Abraham Lincoln, whose re-election in 1864 was largely due to Nevada's expedited entry into statehood; Jack Johnson, who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion; Sarah Winnemucca, a Northern Paiute activist from Nevada; and Mark Twain, who lived and wrote for a newspaper in Virginia City and Carson City, NV in the early 1860s. Each portrait contains a detail pertaining to the individual, for example: buildings on top of DeLonghamps' head; a basket behind the top of Dot So La Lee's head; a brand surrounded by barbed wire on top of Palmer's head; Heizer wears a hat that appears sculpted from metal to symbolize his work as a sculptor; a rendering of the Nevada Historical Society in the broach pinned to Weir's collar; the US Highway sign imposed on Lincoln's head is symbolic of his namesake, US Route 40; a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout; and the top of Twain's head represented as an open book, and a quill pen over his right shoulder.
record.Sitelocation: Eastern wall of Junkee Clothing Exchange at 960 S. Virginia St., Reno, NV
