mods.abstract: This signal box is covered in white birch trees. Artist Clarissa Stephens painted the birches, with their characteristic white bark marked with long, horizontal lenticels (lines), against a background of nearly the same color, using a slightly more gray tone of white and a shading technique to make the birches pop against the white background. A few golden-yellow leaves appear on the tips of some of the birches' branches.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts the profile of a man with a beard, wearing glasses, holding a skull in his hand painted against a half blue (horizontally) red and half sky-background. The man's hair and the back of his head are comprised of: part cloudy blue sky with white swans flying across it, part water with dark-blue fish swimming in it. Large, bright-pink flowers emerge from the bottom-left corner of the mural, getting smaller as they cross the top of the skull and finally speckle the red background between the skull and man's face.

mods.abstract: "DAYDREAM!" appears in all caps in this mural that artist Joe C. Rock painted on a chain link fence with wood slats. Enclosed within the block letters is green grass against a blue skyline. The letters are outlined in white and cast red shadows outlined in peach. Growing out of the grass in the first "D" is a blue flower. A butterfly with blue wings perches on the outside edge of the second "D" and a lady bug crawls across the grass. A red rose rests on the left side of the "R." A worm slithers through the grass, straddling the right side of the "R" and left side of the "E," disappearing and re-emerging out of the right side of the "E." A blue flower with a lady bug on it grows out of the grass in the dot of the exclamation point.

mods.abstract: Christina Angelina's mural, painted during the Inaugural Reno Sculpture Fest in 2015, features a young female figure wearing a dark grey hood over her long wavy black hair. She looks directly at the viewer, and holds a silver frame against her body. The mural was painted using a palette of blues, grays, silver and black and using a technique wherein the paint streams down from the very top of the mural to create movement in the composition. Due to the mural's considerably large scale (approximately 35 x 80 ft.), spanning the entire height of a seven-story parking garage, the young woman seems to look down upon or watch over the downtown-Reno area. After being told by a homeless man in Reno that the young woman is his angel, Angelina said: "That people sleep under this artwork to feel safer downtown [m]akes me like this piece even more" (https://www.instagram.com/p/BUx2SQUlhIj/?hl=en&taken-by=starfightera).

mods.abstract: Artist Hernan Borrero paints an animated bindle-carrying dog smoking in front of an idle motel located in the southwestern desert, suggested by the magenta cacti. The mural is painted in shades of green, pink, purple, yellow, black, and brown. Bryce Chisholm's mural features a a vibrant multicolored background. A young woman on the right and a wolf below her on the left have been painted over the background using a stencil (a technique the artist is known for) and black and white paint. Two thin lines with stars surrounding them encircled the woman. A thin white outline of the number 4 (for 4th Street, where the building upon which the mural resides), surrounded by a blue flourish pattern, are painted in the upper-left side of the mural. A aqua-blue houndstooth pattern has been painted, again with a stencil in the upper-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: Nevada or Nevada Row is a collaborative mural by artists Joe C. Rock and Erik Burke that showcases "...people who made a significant impression on Nevada through unconventional ways. Portraits in blue (the color of the Nevada flag) represent Nevada natives and warm-toned portraits represent outsiders that accomplished something significant in or for Nevada" (eriktburke.com). A wooden arrow with a black obsidian arrowhead runs right to left behind the portraits. The portraits is of Jack Johnson who, after winning a bout against James Jeffries in Reno, NV in 1910, became the first African American world heavyweight boxing champion. Above his head is a rendering of Johnson knocking Jeffries out during the championship bout.

mods.abstract: The theme of this vibrant mural, painted by members of UTI Crew during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, directly relates to the location in which it is painted: the wall of Headquarters Bar, a bar owned and operated by "Crawl Reno, the organizers of the Reno Zombie Crawl and a ton of other massive parties in downtown Reno" (http://headquartersreno.com/#home_about). On the right side of the mural stands a man with characteristics representative of the various crawls that take place in Reno throughout the year. The red Santa hat he wears with gold polka dots and a gold fur ball gestures towards the Santa Crawl; his green beard gestures towards the Leprechaun Crawl; and the Superman shirt he wears gestures towards the Super Hero Crawl. On the left side of the mural is a zombie with a mask resting on the top of its head, representing both the Zombie and Mardi Gras Crawls. These two figures flank four separate graffiti-style words (one of which appears to be the moniker of one of the UTI Crew members, Spek). In the background of the mural, a city skyline goes up in flames, perhaps caused by the man on the left who holds a lit match in his right hand, a mug of bear in his left. To the left of the mural is a small chain link fence with wood slats upon which "The Crawl" is painted in aqua, turquoise and sky blue horror font against a yellow and orange background with red splatters.

mods.abstract: An armor-clad romanesque statue with severed fingers on its left hand stands on the left side of this mural. Green, peach, salmon, lavender, and blue geometric shapes float from behind the stature, against a dark purple background, and upside down bronze-colored fleurs-de-lis (perhaps suggesting that the statue is of French origin) speckle a slate-blue background in the upper-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: Michael Lucido's electric-box mural features two sunglass-wearing raccoons on the back. A raccoon holding a video camera in its right hand while flashing a "sign of the horns" gesture (the index finger and the little finger are upright and the thumb is clasped against the two middle fingers) on his left hand sits atop the shoulders of the other raccoon who is performing a kick flip on a sky-blue skateboard with pink wheels, the words "Rad Thief" (a reference to the name of Lucido's clothing company: Rad Thief) appear on the bottom of the board ("Rad Thief" also appears on the video camera). The raccoons are painted against a teal, yellow, and pink background. Three smaller boxes (one blue, one yellow, one pink) sit to the left of the main box. The skateboarding theme of this box possibly relates to its location at City Park Plaza, used in the past as an unofficial skate park. The video camera might be symbolic Lucido's involvement with multi-media production.

mods.abstract: The front side of Arthur Richmond's signal-box mural features a colorful hummingbird whose red beak wraps around to the left side of the box and ends in a fountain-pen tip. The bird's head is dark blue and green, the green carries into the top of the bird's wing that then transitions to dark brown. The bird's back is light brown, and its breast is light purple, light blue, light green, yellow, brown and white. The bird is perched on the branch of what appears to be a birch tree. What the bird is looking at is reflected in its pupil, which is surrounded by a golden-yellow iris. The bird is painted against a white background at the top of the box that transitions to deep orange at the bottom of the box.

mods.abstract: The front side of this signal box painted by Vaka features a rodeo clown. White circles are painted around the clown's eyes and mouth and red appear around his nose and upper lip. A headset microphone sits in front of the clown's mouth, worn under a white cowboy hat with red trim. The clown's neck is adorned with a red neckerchief, worn above a blue shirt. Behind the clown is a multicolored background speckled with yellow, blue, red and green handprints. The word "Reno" is painted in white over a black backdrop in the lower-right corner of the box. The theme of this signal box relates to its proximity to the Reno Livestock Events Center, the venue for the Reno Rodeo.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.abstract: This gypsy-like woman, painted by artist Anthony Ortega, fashions a combination of deep-red and golden-yellow hair, wrapped in a green and white gypsy headscarf, embellished with a vibrant yellow flower. She is also accented with dangling golden earrings, blue sleeves, and detailed floral designs on her shoulders. She holds a cocktail in her left hand, displaying her connection to Davidson's distillery, the place upon which the mural was painted.

mods.abstract: This mural by Erik Burke was painted on an aluminum garage door using a color palette consisting of white, gray and black, and various shades of blue, green, red and brown. The garage door has been painted lead gray and each square of the individual raised panels are painted in one of seven alternating colors: cinnamon brown, hickory brown, sea-foam green, teal blue, stone blue, cerulean blue, and navy blue. The petals of the poppy in the foreground were created using candy, crimson, cherry, and mahogany red. The curvy stem is a painted using sapphire, cerulean and aegean blue, shaded with gray and highlighted with yellow and light green. A partially crushed coca-cola can appears in the center of the mural, painted over a portion of the stem. The poppy appears to emerge from under a gray roller-style garage door, with the outline of an alien head painted on it in red. The mural is 20 x 8 ft. The garage structure upon which this mural was painted was torn down in Spring of 2018.

mods.abstract: Artist Michael Lucido's electric-box mural depicts a food truck driven and manned by raccoons serving skateboards. The front side portrays the back or non-service side of the food truck. The skateboard-food-truck theme of this box possibly relates to its location at City Park Plaza, used in the past as an unofficial skate park, and to the food-truck culture that has developed in the area over the past several years.

mods.abstract: This signal-box mural by Devin Hosselkus is Reno themed. Reno's slogan,"Reno: the Biggest Little City in the World," wraps around the box, as do renderings of the various versions of the Reno arches (the original version with slogan: installed in 1929; the second version: installed in 1963; and the current version: installed in 1987). Hosselkus used a simple color palette consisting of navy blue, teal, red, tan and brown, grey, white, and black.

mods.abstract: This 65 x (roughly) 16 foot mural pinated on the wall of Peerless Cleaners by artist Erik Burke combines Reno history and Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is speckled with small symbols that depict prominent Reno figures, organizations, and locations in the business's and city's history. Some of these symbols are connected, like constellations, by a line that carries throughout the composition. The mountain-range landscape can also be interpreted as draped fabric, connecting the mural to the the business located in that building. The mural is painted in shades of red, orange, yellow, blue and white.

mods.abstract: This collaborative mural painted by Troy Lovegates and Collin van der Sluijis during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017 portrays several symbols of Nevada's history, landscape, wildlife and fauna. A mountain bluebird is flanked on the left by the upper body of a monochromatic Native American man and on the right by Canadian Geese flying in front of the lower body of a cowboy-boot-wearing individual. The mural is further embellished with feathers, various flowers, pyramids, and red and yellow polka dots.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a landscape scene with prominent snow-capped mountains on the horizon. Two men shake hands in the middle of the mural and two children play in a pile of leaves to the right. A rainbow, a treble clef, and music notes emerge from Louis Armstong's trumpet on the left. The rainbow gets larger as it flows over the hand-shaking men and behind the mountain range on the right, where a blond angel in a pink dress hovers.

mods.abstract: This mural was painted by artist Erik Burke on a cinderblock trash-can enclosure located behind the Nevada Museum of Art (NMA) to coincide with the Tilted Basin Exhibition that ran at the NMA from August through October of 2016. The entire enclose was painted in a vibrant lime green and the male and female figures represented horizontally on the left side, presumably a father and daughter dancing, are painted on top of the lime-green background using darker shades of green and black paint. Dark-green paint was used to create a cat-like design on the portion of the girl's dress that covers her arms, shoulders and upper back, and to create a simple floral pattern on the remaining (lower) portion of the dress. A bit a of white paint was used to create the metal appearance of the man's wedding band and to paint Burke's moniker (OU37) in the upper-left corner. According to the NMA website, the Tilted Basin Exhibition "bridges the divide between Northern and Southern Nevada communities and provides a wide-ranging overview and understanding of the most accomplished work being created by more than thirty artists living and working in Nevada today." This mural was replaced during the 2017 Reno Mural Expo by one painted by artist Dr. Chip Thompson (that mural can be found in this archive under "Unknown [We Are Powerful]).

record.Title: Early To Rise
record.Description: This mural was painted by artist Erik Burke on a cinderblock trash-can enclosure located behind the Nevada Museum of Art (NMA) to coincide with the Tilted Basin Exhibition that ran at the NMA from August through October of 2016. The entire enclose was painted in a vibrant lime green and the male and female figures represented horizontally on the left side, presumably a father and daughter dancing, are painted on top of the lime-green background using darker shades of green and black paint. Dark-green paint was used to create a cat-like design on the portion of the girl's dress that covers her arms, shoulders and upper back, and to create a simple floral pattern on the remaining (lower) portion of the dress. A bit a of white paint was used to create the metal appearance of the man's wedding band and to paint Burke's moniker (OU37) in the upper-left corner. According to the NMA website, the Tilted Basin Exhibition "bridges the divide between Northern and Southern Nevada communities and provides a wide-ranging overview and understanding of the most accomplished work being created by more than thirty artists living and working in Nevada today." This mural was replaced during the 2017 Reno Mural Expo by one painted by artist Dr. Chip Thompson (that mural can be found in this archive under "Unknown [We Are Powerful]).

mods.abstract: The southern wall of Jub Jub's Thirst parlor contains six panels, each painted by a different artist. From left to right: The profile of a man resembling (or perhaps who is) James Brown belting out a tune is the subject of this mural by artist Joe C. Rock. The words "Funk,""Rock,""Soul," and "Style," as well as music notes emerge from and float out of his coifed hair; An armor-clad romanesque statue with severed fingers on its left hand stands on the left side of this mural. Green, peach, salmon, lavender, and blue geometric shapes float from behind the stature, against a dark purple background and upside down bronze-colored fleurs-de-lis (perhaps suggesting that the statue is of French origin) speckle a slate-blue background in the upper-right corner of the mural; Late-rapper TuPac Shakur appears in front a the Los Angeles skyline wearing a red bandana tied around his head, a Detroit Red Wings jersey, and a gold chain and watch. Graffiti-splatters style text painted over paint splatte

mods.abstract: Each side of Bryce Chisholm's signal box portrays a distinct image. On the left side, Chisholm painted this "Super Boy" using white, black, and red paint and a stencil (a technique he is known for). Outfitted in a red and black cape and mask, with a star emblazoned on his chest, the boy strikes a heroic pose as an aqua-blue and black (stencil painted) moon emerges over the boy from the vibrant yellow background. Purple and teal roots can be seen growing below the boy's feet. A halo-like object has been painted with white paint (and a stencil) over the boy's head.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock depicts a cowboy riding a wild mustang into the sunset, representative of the Reno Rodeo, in this mural painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October, 2017. A halo of barbed wire floats above the cowboy's hat and a locomotive disguises itself in the body of the mustang. The background is painted bright blue with a beige banner swirling across it that reads "Get Buck Get Broke." Objects, such as grape bundles, crowns (a common object in Rock's murals), hearts and cherries speckle the mural's background.

record.Title: Get Buck, Get Broke

mods.abstract: This signal box is covered in white birch trees. Artist Clarissa Stephens painted the birches, with their characteristic white bark marked with long, horizontal lenticels (lines), against a background of nearly the same color, using a slightly more gray tone of white and a shading technique to make the birches pop against the white background. A few golden-yellow leaves appear on the tips of some of the birches' branches.

mods.abstract: This monochromatic mural set against a light blue background depicts a camera with a roll of film unraveling from its film compartment. On the unraveled film can be seen the undeveloped images that the camera has captured. A girl holds her dog; a man hangs out the driver-side window of a van and looks at the camera; a man kneels in front of his bicycle; two children ride their bicycles; a man looks to his left with a city street behind him; a man holds two bags (one in each hand) up in the air and smiles at the camera; a woman stands with her hands in her pockets and smiles at the camera; a young girl looks quizzically at the camera; a young man looks back at the camera from the driver-side window of his car; a man stands with his hands in his pockets in front of a light pole; a man with a thick mustache looks directly at the camera, a skull-like object is to the left of him; four children sit together on some steps; a young girl rides a rocking horse. The film roll ends, leading into an orange burst and then beam of light that perhaps represents the light needed to expose the film. The light beam is surrounded by black, blue, and gray clouds.

mods.abstract: This mural painted by artist Erik Burke embraces the history of Nevada. Similar to his other murals, this work is composed of two elements: a landscape, and the words "GO WEST." The landscape depicts the variety of mountain ranges in Nevada, suggested by the variety of color (shades of red and blue) in which they are painted. The landscape also portrays a wild mustang, an animal representative of Nevada's "wild west" nature and reputation. On the right side of the mural appears a female figure holding a lantern, as if guiding the horse, and throwing into relief the words "GO WEST." The words are painted in a subtle yellow and white that merges them into the landscape. The lines in between the words, which depict birch trees with Basque tree carvings that are found in the state, weave in front of and behind the mustang and run parallel (and in some cases line up directly with) the building behind the mural (the Silver Legacy Hotel & Casino), further connecting the mural to the city.

record.Title: Unknown [Go West]

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock combines United States history with the history of Nevada in this mural that was commissioned to celebrate the Historic Lincoln Highway. Abraham Lincoln appears on the left side of the mural, leading to the Nevada flag and then U.S. flag, over which the words "LINCOLN HIGHWAY" are painted in different font styles and are flanked by the Nevada flag and the Interstate 40 highway sign. All subjects combined, this mural conveys the relevance of this president and his namesake highway.

mods.abstract: This painted-wall sign welcomes those driving past it to Dickerson Road, an area west of downtown Reno, running parallel to the Truckee River, that is referred to as "'Reno’s Industrial Arts District,' combining art, commercial and residential properties, and a nature preserve." Using bright and vibrant colors, Eric (Erik) Burke and Buz Rhodes painted large block letters, with orange and red shadows behind them, to spell out "Dickerson," with imagery and scenes appearing in each letter that signify and represent the nature of the district. The "D" features an angle grinder cutting metal; a paint brush stands in for the "I"; the "C" features the profile of half of a sandwich; the "K" displays a smith forging a piece of metal; the "E" shows someone wearing tan pants and brown boots laying under the hood of a vehicle; the "R" features a woman's body in profile from her lower torso to the top of her knees, wearing a black and white striped undergarment, with red rose vines over the entire image; the "S" contains water with green and purple lily pads floating on top; the "O" is made up of a figure wearing tan garments throwing on a yellow pottery wheel; and the "N" includes a variety of multicolored metal bottle caps. The words "Welcome to" and "Live, Work, Eat, Play" appear in red and blue on a white banner painted on the left side of the mural. The artists' names,"Eric Burke and Buz Rhodes," appear in red and blue on a white banner painted in the upper far-right corner of the mural.

mods.abstract: A fluid mural is painted by artist Joe C. Rock on this three-sided fence. The mural begins with the head of a woman in front of clouds whose hair then flows throughout the mural, as do the clouds. An array of subject matter appear among the hair and clouds over a light-blue background. While some figures portray recognizable figures, such as dice, eye balls, power lines, butterflies, rain drops, a bee, a rose, a mountain range, and botehs (the teardrop-shaped motif with a curved upper end that comprises the paisley pattern), other subjects and figures are more abstract, or focus on written text.

mods.abstract: This mural depicts a large brown octopus mixed with peacock feathers and a human-like figure. The octopus is the focus of the mural. The body of the octopus is painted in a palette of browns, while its suckers are painted in a palette of blue. The peacock feathers almost resemble the suckers as they intertwine into the octopus's tentacles. The tentacles wrap around and burst through a portrait of a blue human-like figure wearing headphones that emerges from the mud-cracked ground, perhaps representing Burning Man since the business upon which the mural is painted, The Melting Pot World Emporium, is one of the leading retailers of Playa gear in the area. The figure stares out into the distance. A tentacle bursts through the middle portrait, which depicts the Burning Man logo centered in the Burning-Man-Playa landscape with planets hanging in the night sky above. The last portrait is a circus-style wall sign for the The Melting Pot. A curtain opens up to a stage with silhouettes of people dancing in front of an earth with sun rays around it. The background of the entire mural is painted a bright red, contrasting the aquatic and desert ambiance of the subject matter.

mods.abstract: Artist Erik Burke paints a sitting human figure with yellow, peach, orange and white skin comprised of puzzle pieces holding a roller door with the outline of a house painted on it close to his/her body. The door covers most of the figure, including his/her face. Also held against the body, in front of the door, is a lime green chain attached to a turquoise foam finger displaying the ""Sign of the Horns"" gesture. A set of red and white die attached to a silver ball chain hang from the pinky finger of the foam finger. To the right of this, a dark orange and peach block arrow with a dumbbell and arrow with feathers inside of it emerges from three concentric triangles in different shades of green from which a gold alligator mouth emerges. From this mouth comes a peach-outlined-in-dark-orange text bubble with a curly-cue tail that says ""ND'A OU33""(OU33 being Burke's moniker). Above the mouth, the word ""Flyge"" or ""Flyce"" is depicted with real rocks glued to an aqua blue banner-like background.

mods.abstract: As artist Joe C. Rock explains on his website: "This mural was created as an ode to the history of the Midtown area in Reno, NV. The word 'Midtown' covers the wall in painted exposed brick, transitioning from new, to worn down, to built back up with metal and brackets, just as the area has [b]een throughout the years. Vintage ads and photographs of [influential] people and businesses, [as well as] imagery that helped build up the area are recreated in spray paint and house paint [and] collaged about in a makeshift timeline of the area [that leads] up to a motel sign from the street, re-lettered to say 'look to the future.' A child adorned in an American-flag dress with Lady Liberty's crown, torch, and tablets looks blindly into the future."

mods.abstract: Four different-colored, equally-sized squares (clockwise from the top left: green, blue, red, yellow) are painted against a solid-black wall. Along the bottom of the wall, below and in front of the red and yellow squares, the downtown Reno skyline has been depicted with a white outline over black paint. Above the skyline and in the middle of the four squares, a colored portrait of downtown Reno with depictions of the various iterations of the arches has been painted on what was once a plain white piece of paper like those floating around the portrait and composition. "Reno Paint Mart" and paint drops in a variety of colors appear in the upper-right corner of the mural. *The other pieces of paper are slowly being painted to depict other scenes relating to Reno. This was the progress at the time of this photograph.

mods.abstract: In this collaborative piece painted by Erik Burke, Kelly Peyton, and Kaitlyn Bryson, a male figure wearing dark blue jeans and a yellow tank top lays on his back in front of a blue background with hands interlaced and resting on his stomach. It appears as though the man is floating. In the bottom-left corner of the mural, circular, triangular, other geometric shapes, and dashes are painted on the man's pants in a shade of blue lighter than the pants and more like that of the background. Similar shapes are painted in marigold yellow on the man's shirt, as are figures fashioned out of the letters "L" and "D" and the number "4" (L4, D4); these figures represent the phrase "Live for What You Would Die For." These figures, and the phrase they represent, likely relate to the theme and purpose of the mural, referred to by one if its painters, Burke, as a tribute to Beau Shaver of Reno, NV who is also likely the man depicted in the mural. The man also has various shapes (hearts, roses, the outline of a crown) and words painted in yellow on his arm, neck, face and teeth. The background of the right side of the mural is painted in graduated shades of blue (light to dark, from the bottom to the top). An upside down brown hat appears in the lower-right corner of the mural, it has currant-red-outlined-in-yellow flowers sitting on the brim and one flower peaking out from inside. Burke's moniker (OU33), the other two artists' initials (KP and Kb), and the date (2012) are painted in white in the upper-right corner of the mural, with "L4D4 SODC SHAVER" painted below. The mural is 80 x 16 ft.

Painted on a wall of the 3rd St. Flats that now occupy the building that used to be the Kings Inn Casino, the blue crown floating above the bird's head symbolizes the old establishment's signage: a crown resting on top of the "K" in King.

mods.abstract: Artist Joe C. Rock paints a Mt. Rose-themed mural on this 20 x 50 foot wall. The profiles of two women disguise themselves in roses that transition from orange to mustard yellow to golden yellow and decorate the bottom third of the mural. Two pine cones peak from behind the roses, making way to the idyllic rendering of a snow-capped Mt. Rose against a tranquil blue sky. Sage-green leaves and pine needles, with a lady bug crawling through those in the middle right, frame the top of the mural.

mods.abstract: In one of the largest murals painted during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, artist Sebastian Coolidge paints a child's legs lying in a grass field. Across from the child is a lone purple flower that appears to be blown by the wind. Large stems sprout throughout the mural and one intersects the child's blue shoe that has a tiny bee resting on the tip of its upper sole. Above this and slightly to the left, a nose emerges from the grass. A thin yellow worm or caterpillar, with a small purple stone in the shape of a head and face to its left, originates from a leaf on a stem and bounces on the grass and enters the child's left thigh.

mods.abstract: The theme of Erik Burke's mural, A World Away, relates to Mexican culture and the restaurant upon which it is painted: Miguel's. The entire mural consists of four different walls (two west facing, one south facing, and one north facing), each with its own scene painted on it. A muted greenish blue is carried throughout the background of the entire mural. On the west-facing wall on the left, the naturally occurring door and surround are painted over to appear older and more substantial. In the middle of the wall is a church with a green and blue stone and stucco facade with red trim, and people are gathered outside. To the right of this, a red cactus pear is painted in front of what appears to be a black, white and red striped sarape. As Burke explains on his website, he painted on the middle south-facing wall a "Memorial portrait of Miguel Ribera (original owner and namesake of [the] restaurant) with the phrase 'Out of This World,' [which] represents both his passing, as well as his passion for extra-terrestrial life." Ribera is painted against a plain brown background on the top half of the wall and brown and black basket-weave-like pattern on the bottom half. "Out of This World" is painted in the muted greenish blue that's carried through the entire mural. Burke's moniker (OU38) is painted in the lower-left corner of the wall. The west-facing wall on the right contains a scene of a woman with braided hair rolling tortillas. Light pink and lavender plumerias with yellow centers are painted in front of the same sarape that appears on the left west-facing wall. Burke's moniker is also painted on the lower-right corner of this wall. The adjacent north-facing wall is painted with thick stripes: brown, yellow, white, red, blue, black, brown, yellow, green. According to Burke, this mural is based on personal photos he took while in Oaxaca and on Diego Rivera's painting, La Molendera.

"Out of This World" is painted in the muted greenish blue that's carried through the entire mural. Burke's moniker (OU38) is painted in the lower-left corner of the wall. The west-facing wall on the right contains a scene of a woman with braided hair rolling tortillas. Light pink and lavender plumerias with yellow centers are painted in front of the same sarape that appears on the left west-facing wall. Burke's moniker is also painted on the lower-right corner of this wall. The adjacent north-facing wall is painted with thick stripes: brown, yellow, white, red, blue, black, brown, yellow, green. According to Burke, this mural is based on personal photos he took while in Oaxaca and on Diego Rivera's painting, La Molendera.

record.Title: A World Away
record.Description: The theme of Erik Burke's mural, A World Away, relates to Mexican culture and the restaurant upon which it is painted: Miguel's. The entire mural consists of four different walls (two west facing, one south facing, and one north facing), each with its own scene painted on it. A muted greenish blue is carried throughout the background of the entire mural. On the west-facing wall on the left, the naturally occurring door and surround are painted over to appear older and more substantial. In the middle of the wall is a church with a green and blue stone and stucco facade with red trim, and people are gathered outside. To the right of this, a red cactus pear is painted in front of what appears to be a black, white and red striped sarape. As Burke explains on his website, he painted on the middle south-facing wall a "Memorial portrait of Miguel Ribera (original owner and namesake of [the] restaurant) with the phrase 'Out of This World,' [which] represents both his passing, as well as his passion for extra-terrestrial life." Ribera is painted against a plain brown background on the top half of the wall and brown and black basket-weave-like pattern on the bottom half. "Out of This World" is painted in the muted greenish blue that's carried through the entire mural. Burke's moniker (OU38) is painted in the lower-left corner of the wall. The west-facing wall on the right contains a scene of a woman with braided hair rolling tortillas. Light pink and lavender plumerias with yellow centers are painted in front of the same sarape that appears on the left west-facing wall. Burke's moniker is also painted on the lower-right corner of this wall. The adjacent north-facing wall is painted with thick stripes: brown, yellow, white, red, blue, black, brown, yellow, green. According to Burke, this mural is based on personal photos he took while in Oaxaca and on Diego Rivera's painting, La Molendera.
record.Sitelocation: Southern and western walls of Miguel's Mexican Restaurant at 1415 S. Virginia St., Reno, NV

mods.abstract: Alley Cats, painted by Miami-based artist Fallen Rose during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, depicts cats in several different modes. The cats in each wall are painted in black, but the background is different in each wall. Some walls are multicolored, while some are simplistic or monochromatic.

mods.abstract: Erik Burke paints vibrant and crisp orange poppy-like flowers with yellow and black centers against a background of steel, deep sky and powder blue leaf-like figures. The silhouette of stems and flowers without petals are cast sporadically throughout the composition, at times intersecting the poppy-like flowers, thus taking on a translucent appearance and revealing details of the poppy-like flowers they intersect. The words "Back in the Day is Now" are painted across the mural in a translucent white, again revealing details of the poppy-like flowers over which they are painted. The starkly-contrasting colors of the mural allow the bright flowers in the foreground to stand out and pop against the more subdued background. The mural is 130 x 24 ft.

mods.abstract: When describing his mural, Portrait of a Mother, artist Erik Burke states: "a woman in profile, a carnation, sagebrush, and Mount Whitney overlay one another. The woman (my wife and new mother) was used as a nurturing figure depicted in rich calming blueprint blue. She tends her flock of sheep patterned across her blouse that rises from Mount Whitney, the highest summit in the contiguous United States and the Sierra Nevada. She is flanked by Nevada's state flower, the wild and ever present sagebrush. An enlarged carnation obscures her head but is aligned in a way to represent the entangled and beautiful workings of the brain. Although the carnation has no direct tie to the area, I chose it because it has long been cultivated by many and varying civilizations for decoration and ceremonial purposes, similar to the contemporary use of murals" (eriktburke.com/Blueprint-of-a-Mother). Burke utilized a simple color palette consisting of: a variety of blue shades for the woman, her shirt, and the mountains (which were also painted using gray, white, and black); pinks and reds for the carnation; dark green for the stem of the carnation and a blueish green for the sagebrush, which extends past the parameters of the main mural and casts a gray shadow. Burke's moniker (OU36) is painted in dark blue at the very top, in the middle of the mural, and his website address (eriktburke.com) is painted in white on the bottom-left corner. The mural, 35 x 80 ft., was painted on the seven-story parking garage of Whitney Peak Hotel, during the Inaugural Sculpture Fest in 2015 in Downtown Reno.

The silhouette of stems and flowers without petals are cast sporadically throughout the composition, at times intersecting the poppy-like flowers, thus taking on a translucent appearance and revealing details of the poppy-like flowers they intersect. The words "Back in the Day is Now" are painted across the mural in a translucent white, again revealing details of the poppy-like flowers over which they are painted. The starkly-contrasting colors of the mural allow the bright flowers in the foreground to stand out and pop against the more subdued background. The mural is 130 x 24 ft.

mods.abstract: Day Dream, by Joe C. Rock, is inspired by Reno culture, particularly the popularity of Burning Man. The two central figures are wrapped in an embrace, sporting typical attire for Burning Man. The veil on the head of the figure on the left suggests that the mural might be depicting a "Playa Wedding." One head morphs into a electrocardiograph line that bleeds into the Nevada mountain ranges. The mural is painted with shades of blue, red, yellow, orange, brown, black, and white.

mods.abstract: Artist Dave Young Kim, who painted this mural during the Inaugural Reno Mural Expo in October of 2017, explains his mural as follows: "Before and during World War II the Japanese army took [hundreds] of thousands of girls, mostly from Korea, China and the Philippines, as sex slaves. These 'comfort women' were often times as young as 13 when they were kidnapped, lured in by promises of debt resolution or work. The smile symbolizes the innocence that was lost, and the pink carnations say we will never forget. The open sign completes the piece. History is only history when it no longer happens. Although legal in the state of Nevada, prostitution is illegal in Reno and Las Vegas [and] yet more than 90% of the profits come from those two cities. The same tactics are used today to lure underage girls into a world they never suspected. There are more slaves today than there ever were in history" (https://www.instagram.com/p/BanqFu7lcpm/?hl=en&taken-by=daveyoungkim).

mods.abstract: Three children and an instructor playing the piano are the subject of this music-themed mural painted by artist Erik Burke on the 60 x 18 foot northern wall of (what was) Maytan Music Center. The brown-haired boy on the left, wearing a red-patterned shirt, has his disproportionately-sized hands stretched out in front of him, resting above the piano keys. The blond-haired girl wearing a purple shirt with a butterfly on it, places both of her hands flat on the keys and smiles widely. The blond-haired boy on the right, wearing glasses and a red and blue striped shirt, plays the piano with his just two index fingers. A headless adult figure (probably an instructor) wearing a white shirt with a yellow "MM" (Make your Momentum) logo on it stands between the blond-haired girl and boy, his/her hands rest on the keys in the full C Major hand position (gesturing towards the mural's title, C Major 7).
